questions.text: Identify the bone related to the ear:
questions.solution:
• The middle ear ossicle shown in the given image is Incus. It's an anvil shaped bone.  
  • It has a body, a short process and a long process. 
  • It articulates with malleus laterally ( saddle joint ) and stapedius medially ( ball and socket joint )
  • The long process of incus is susceptible to ischemic necrosis due to a single nutrient artery and lack of collateral circulation.

Parts of Incus





Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat by PL Dhingra, 7th edition, Page no 9, 165.

questions.text: Which ligament is derived from the structure marked with green arrow:
questions.solution:
The structure marked by the green arrow is ventral mesentery and among the given options, falciform ligament is it's derivative. 

1. Derivatives of dorsal mesentery-
  • Greater omentum,
  • gastrosplenic,
  • gastrophrenic and
  • lienorenal ligament.

2. Derivatives of ventral mesentery-
  • Lesser omentum and
  • All ligaments of liver ( falciform, triangular and coronary ligaments ) except ligamentum teres.



Reference: Langman’s Medical Embryology, 14th edition, Page no 233, 236-239.

questions.text: Identify the histological slide:
questions.solution:
The given histological slide shows islet cells of pancreas which constitute the endocrine part of pancreas.
 
  • These are secretory cells which appear paler ( less pink ) as compared to surrounding exocrine cells.
  • This is due to the fact that the endocrine cells contain less rough endoplasmic reticulum when compared to the exocrine part. 




Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 898, 1097.

questions.text: Identify the given histological image :
questions.solution:
The given histological slide is suggestive of fibrocartilage which is characterized by prominent collagen fibers arranged in the form of bundles with intervening rows of chondrocytes. 

The features of fibrocartilage are-
 
  1. Absent perichondrium
  2. Chondrocytes which are round in shape and arranged in rows between collagen bundles. 
  3. Ground substance containing type 1 collagen fibers



Reference: Inderbir Singh’s Textbook of Human Histology, 8th edition, Page no 56-59.

questions.text: To promote lifespan, best recommendation is:
questions.solution:
Among the given options, best answer would be reduction in calorie intake.
 
  • The plausible explanation is that calorie restriction results in decreased rate of energy metabolism which in turn reduces the degree of oxidative damage.
 
  • It does so by increasing the levels of sirtuins ( NAD dependant protein deacetylases ) and reducing signaling intensity of insulin like growth factor (IGF) 1. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 67-69.

choices.text: Phase I denotes pressure due to residual volume
Phase II is in accordance with Laplace law
Voluntary control is not possible in Phase III
Detrusor muscle remains relaxed in Phase IV

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding given cystometrogram?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a cystometrogram which is a graphical plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of urine in bladder.

I- It is the initial slight rise in pressure when the urinary bladder begins to receive urine post void and not due to residual volume.

II- It is a long and flat segment. The Laplace's law is obeyed in this segment. As tension increases due to progressive filling of bladder with urine, there is only slight increase in pressure until the bladder is relatively full. 

III- A sharp and sudden rise due to trigger of micturition reflex and not its failure. 

IV- Detrusor muscle will contract ( not relax ) after initiation of micturition reflex. 




Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 681, 682.

questions.text: Extracellular concentration of potassium can be decreased by:
questions.solution:
• Epinephrine is an agonist at alpha 1, beta 1 and beta 2 receptors.
 
  • Through it's action on Beta receptors in liver and muscle, it increases the expression of Na+-K+ ATPase pumps on the cell membrane which results in increased intracellular uptake of potassium causing hypokalemia. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 142, 145.

questions.text: What kind of signaling is shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Paracrine signaling. In paracrine signaling, the signaling molecules which are secreted by a cell will act on the target cells in its close proximity. 

Example- Conduction of electric impulse from one nerve cell to another or from nerve cell to muscle occurs via paracrine signaling. 



Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 53, 54.

questions.text: Study the graph and answer the body effect, if the hypothalamic set of point of temperature is raised rapidly (dotted blue line):
questions.solution:
In the given graph, the patient's hypothalamic thermostat has been reset from point V to a higher temperature- point X. 

Therefore, in order to reset to the new higher temperature, the body will activate various heat gain mechanisms to match the new hypothalamic set point. 

The various mechanisms are as follows-

1. Shivering ( Option D )

2. Vasoconstriction

3. Chemical thermogenesis in the brown fat



Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th edition, Page no 901-910.

questions.text: What kind of mechanism is involved in Baroreceptor reflex?
questions.solution:
Baroreceptor is an example of negative feedback mechanism.

Option A- Feedforward mechanism responds to anticipation of a change of regulated variable. Example- Increased secretion of insulin when meal reaches digestive tract.

Option C- Positive feedback mechanism refers to enhancement of amplification of the output which moves in the direction of the initial change. Eg- LH surge which is positively regulated by estrogen. 



Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 576-579.

choices.text: A fibers are more prone to pressure than C fibers
C fibers are more prone to pressure than A fibers
A  fibers are more prone to hypoxia than C fibers
C fibers are more prone to hypoxia than A fibers

questions.text: A patient slept the whole night keeping his arm under his head. The next morning when he woke up, he had paresis and numbness in that upper limb. Which of the following physiological fact is true in relation to the clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has developed paresis with intact pain sensation. The reason being A fibers which carry motor sensations are more susceptible to pressure changes/compression than C fibers which carry pain sensations. 


Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 91-93.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Warburg effect?
questions.solution:
Warburg effect is a phenomenon characterized by increased rate of glucose uptake and conversion into lactose even in the presence of oxygen. 

Even though Warburg effect generates only 2 molecules of ATP, it leaves behind adequate carbon moieties which can be used as building blocks for lipids and proteins. 

Oxidative phosphorylation on the other hand leaves behind no carbon moieties as glucose is entirely converted to CO2 and H2O. 

This property of cancer cells of glucose hunger ( Warburg Effect ) is used to visualize them via positron emission tomography ( PET ) scanning. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 299, 300.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is deficient in McArdle's disease?
questions.solution:
McArdle's disease, also known as type V glycogen disease, is an autosomal recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of myophosphorylase- muscle glycogen phosphorylase. 

Option A- Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency results in Hers disease-type VI glycogen storage disease.

Option C- Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase results in Von Gierke Disease- Type I glycogen storage disease.

Option D- Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency results in hemolytic anemia with characteristic bite cells on peripheral smear. 



Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 175.

questions.text: A codon is mutated to a stop codon. What kind of mutation is this?
questions.solution:
A single mutation in a nucleotide base pair which results in incorporation of termination codon is known as nonsense mutation. 

Option A- Mis-sense is a type of point mutation where new codon codes for a different amino acid.

Option C- Stop mutation can be used interchangeably with non sense mutation.

Option D- Frameshift mutation is characterized by altered reading frame due to addition or deletion of nucleotides. 



Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 267, 268.

questions.text: Which of the following is a complex-IV inhibitor:
questions.solution:
Cyanide is an inhibitor of cytochrome complex IV. 

Trick- Inhibitors of complex IV end with -IDE Eg- hydrogen sulfide, carbon monoxide, cyanide, sodium azide. 

Option A- CO2 is an end product of oxidative phosphorylation.

Option C-Oligomycin blocks the flow of protons, thus inhibiting synthesis of ATP. 

Option D- Malonate is an inhibitor of complex II



Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 123, 145, 472.

questions.text: Which of the following brings about DNA packing?
questions.solution:
The proteins involved in DNA packaging are histones. They are rich in positively charged amino acids like histidine. 



Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 107, 339, 342, 343.

choices.text: With ageing, the length of the telomere shortens gradually

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding telomere and telomerase:
questions.solution:
Decrease in telomere length is seen with ageing. 

Option A- Telomeres do not have coding sequences. They are important for prevention of end replication error and the ends from fusion and degradation. 

Option B- Cancer cells as well as stem cells have high telomerase activity allowing them to have endless replication potential. 

Option D- Telomerase maintains the length the chromosome rather than causing its shortening. 



Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 355.
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 303, 304.

questions.text: A Mediterranean person was taking primaquine and he developed hemolytic anemia. It was found that he was having G-6-PD deficiency. Which of the pathway is associated with this clinical syndrome?
questions.solution:
Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is an enzyme of HMP pathway.  It's primary role is to generate NADPH which is essential to form reduced glutathione. 

The reduced glutathione is essential to maintain integrity of erythrocytes against oxidative stress.


Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 157, 172, 175, 182.
Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 782, 784.

questions.text: Transport of fatty acids through the mitochondrial membrane occurs via:
questions.solution:
Carnitine is required for transport of fatty acids across inner mitochondrial membrane. 

It's deficiency can lead to hypoglycemia and restrictive or dilated cardiomyopathy. 


Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 133, 207, 208, 217.

questions.text:
A 4 year old male child presented to paediatrics OPD with anemia, thrombocytopenia and bony pain. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly was noticed. Bone marrow aspirate reveals " crumpled tissue paper " appearance.



What is the most likely enzyme defect in this condition?

A. Glucocerebrosidase
B. Sphingomyelinase
C. Hexosaminidase
D. Glucose-6-phosphatase
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario is suggestive of Gaucher's disease. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion and characterized by deficiency of the enzyme beta-glucocerebrosidase.
  • This leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in various organs, particularly the liver, spleen, and bone marrow. 
  • Accumulation in liver/spleen leads to Hepatsplenomegaly. 
  • Due to bone marrow involvement, patients often have pancytopenia. Bony involvement often leads to bony pains and avascualr necrosis.
Other options

Option B- Deficiency of sphingomyelinase results in Neimann Pick disease.

Option C- Deficiency of hexosaminidase causes Sandhoff disease.

Option D- Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphtase results in Von Gierke Disease-type 1 GSD. 


Reference: Nelson’s Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 771-773.

questions.text: Which of the following disease has got an autosomal recessive inheritance?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Option B-Cystic fibrosis is inherited in autosomal recessive manner. 

Rest of the given options are inherited in autosomal dominant fashion. 


Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2176, 2177, 3216, 3404.

Learn more about cystic fibrosis in the video below:

questions.text: A young person dies of COVID-19 infection. A lung autopsy, what is the significant findings?
questions.solution:
The characteristic finding on lung autopsy in a patient with COVID-19 is a thick layer of fibrin or waxy hyaline membrane lining the alveolar wall. 



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1508, 1509, 2225-2227.
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 677.

questions.text: A young male presented with infertility. Semen analysis showed azoospermia. Testicular biospy was done, the image of which is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with biopsy showing presence of only Sertoli cells, thickening of tubular basement with absence of germ cells is characteristic of Sertoli only cell syndrome. 

Option C- Testicular atrophy is characterized by thickening of basement membrane with absence of spermatids and germ cells. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 974.
Shaw’s Textbook of Gynecology, 16th edition, Page no 241, 242.

questions.text: A 55 years old male presented with complaints of weakness, pallor, weight loss and a dragging sensation in the abdomen. Per abdomen examination revealed massive splenomegaly. Blood pictures showed marked leucoytosis and raised platelet count. Peripheral smear showed myelocytes and metamyelocytes. The peripheral smear image is given below. Which of the following translocation would be seen in such a case?
questions.solution:
The findings of massive splenomegaly with peripheral smear findings of leucocytosis, increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes and basophils go in favor of chronic myeloid leukemia. 

It is characterized by a reciprocal balanced translocation between t(9;22) causing the formation of the BCR-ABL fusion gene which codes for a 210 kDalton constitutively active tyrosine kinase. 

Option (1)- 8;14 translocation is seen in Burkitt Lymphoma. 

Option (2)- 8;21 translocation is seen in AML M2

Option (4)- 15;17 translocation is seen in AML M3 (APML)



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 601, 602, 617-624.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 826.

questions.text: Rupture of saccular aneurysm results in:
questions.solution:
Subarachnoid hemorrhage is seen due to rupture of a saccular aneurysm.  Clinically it presents with sudden onset thunder clap headache. It maybe associated with seizures, unresponsiveness and vomiting. 

The imaging modality of choice for suspected SAH is NC-CT brain which will show hyperdense blood in basal cisterns. This should be followed by a CT Angiography to localize the site of aneurysm which appears as round contrast filled outpouching. 

Treatment is by doing craniotomy with clipping or endovascular coil embolization. 

Option B- Subdural hemorrhage occurs due to rupture of bridging cortical veins. 

Option C- Epidural hemorrhage occurs due to injury to branches of middle meningeal artery from fracture of underlying bone. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1258, 1259.

Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 335, 652, 653.

questions.text: A patient presented with hemoglobinuria, hemosiderinuria, elevated unconjugated bilirubin and elevated LDH levels. Peripheral smear is shown below. Which of the following is related to such a condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of hemoglobinuria, hemosiderinuria, elevated unconjugated bilirubin, and LDH with peripheral smear showing schistocytes are suggestive of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA). 

Amongst the given options, prosthetic cardiac valves will produce and can cause MAHA. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 647, 650.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 785, 786.

questions.text: A 40 years old white raced male presented with a slow growing small nodule on the nose medial to inner canthus of eye. Later on, it ulcerated. Biopsy of the lesion was done and the histopathological image is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a slow growing nodule on face and histopathological image showing peripheral palisading makes the diagnosis go in favor of basal cell carcinoma. 

Basal cell carcinoma does not show any distant metastasis as the tumor tends to destroy its own lymphatic supply. 

Management is by Moh's microscopic surgery. 



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 651.

questions.text: Cystoscopic evaluation of a post-transplant patient revealed multiple soft, yellowish raised plaque in the urinary bladder mucosa. A histopathological examination of the plaque is shown in the image below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Cystoscopy findings of multiple yellow white plaques with histopathology showing Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are consistent with malakoplakia. 

It is an example of inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis due to acquired defects in phagocyte function. This results in large foamy macrophages with abundant granular cytoplasm due to phagosomes stuffed with undigested bacterial products. This coupled with intracellular deposition of calcium and iron within enlarged lysosomes form laminated basophilic concretions knows as Michaelis Gutmann bodies. 

They are pathognomonic of malakoplakia. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 955-957.

questions.text: An adult male with history of long-standing hemorrhoids developed weakness and lethargy. Blood tests revealed a hemoglobin of 7.5 g/dl. Peripheral blood smear is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of Hb ~ 7.5 g/dl in a patient of long standing hemorrhoids ( which results in blood loss ) with peripheral blood smear showing microcytic hypochromic anemia with anisopoikilocytosis is diagnostic of iron deficiency anemia. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 641-644.

questions.text: What is the route of metastasis of carcinoma prostate to lumbar vertebra:
questions.solution:
Carcinoma of prostate commonly spreads to lumbar vertebra through prostatic veous plexus which in turn into prevertebral venous plexus of Batson. 

It commonly gives rise to osteoblastic metastasis. 



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1468-1473.

questions.text: A young female developed a slow growing mass in the middle anterior part of the neck. After few months, she had enlargement of cervical lymph nodes on both the sides. She was subjected to biopsy and the histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following is NOT the true statement regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with histopathological finding of Orphan Annie Eye nuclei goes in favor of papillary cancer of thyroid. 

Option A- Papillary Ca of thyroid shows a characteristic appearance of nucleus known as Orphan Annie Eye due to preinucleolar clearing. 

Option B- It carries an excellent prognosis among the thyroid cancers.

Option C- It can be diagnosed on FNAC unlike follicular carcinoma. It can be diagnosed on FNAC just on the basis of its nuclear features. 

Option D- It commonly spreads via lymphatics. Lungs are the most common site for distant metastasis for papillary Ca of thyroid. 



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 817-819.
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1087-1089.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of MEN2B syndrome?
questions.solution:
MEN 2B syndrome also known as MEN 3 occurs due to mutation of RET proto oncogene on chromosome 10. 

The associated conditions are-

Medullary Ca of thyroid, Pheochromocytoma, Mucosal neuromas, Marfanoid habitus, Medullated corneal nerve fibers and megacolon 



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2983, 2988-2990.

questions.text: A patient with meningitis was subjected to lumbar puncture. Gross appearance of CSF specimen is shown in the first image. CSF findings were low sugar, raised protein and mononuclear leucocytosis. Most likely diagnosis :
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with CSF findings of cobweb like clot and slide showing lymphocytic predominance goes in favor of tuberculous meningitis. 



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1100, 1102-1106.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding Neutrophil Extracellular Trap EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Neutrophil Extracellular trap is extrusion of nuclear DNA ( not mitochondrial ) as a last resort against sepsis. 

The trap provides a scaffolding on which the anti-bacterial substances get deposited along with entrapment of organisms. This helps in elimination of organisms from the bloodstream. 

It is derived from amino acid arginine. 
          


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 83, 84.

questions.text: MDR-TB is defined as resistance to:
questions.solution:
MDR TB is defined as resistance to both isoniazid and rifampicin. 


Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 961, 1359, 1372, 1376.

questions.text:
A 50 years old male who was recently diagnosed as pulmonary TB, was started on ATT. Later on, he presented with the complaints of tingling and numbness over fingers. He is also a chronic alcoholic. This patient should be managed by starting: 
1. Vitamin B1 
2. Vitamin B3
3. Vitamin B6 
4. Vitamin B12
questions.solution:
The features of tingling and numbness over fingers in a patient on anti-tubercular treatment is an adverse effect of isoniazid. 

It occurs due to peripheral neuritis which results from interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine. Therefore, pyridoxine 10 mg/day- Vitamin B6 is given prophylactically with isoniazid in order to prevent this adverse effect. 



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 775, 2526.

questions.text: A known case of COPD was started on I/V theophylline after which he developed diuresis. Such an action of theophylline is mediated through which receptors?
questions.solution:
Increased urine output after administering theophylline is due to antagonism of A1 receptors. 

These receptors are normally preset in afferent arteriole of glomerulus. On activation, they cause vasoconstriction which reduces GFR and decreases urine output. Antagonism of this action will result in increase in GFR and RBF causing increased urine output. 



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 733-735.

questions.text: Hypolipidemic drug, which acts by inhibiting PCSK-9:
questions.solution:
Option A- Rosuvastatin acts by inhibiting HMG CoA reductase, which is the rate limiting enzyme of cholesterol synthesis. 

Option B- Clofibrate stimulates PPAR-alpha which increases fatty acid oxidation and LPL synthesis. This inturn reduces triglycerides, LDL and HDL. 

Option C- Evolocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor. 

Option D- Ezetemibe inhibits cholesterol absorption in the small intestine. 



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 613-615.

questions.text: A young patient consumed 8 tablets of 0.25 mg of Digoxin and developed features of digoxin toxicity. His heart rate was 55 beats/minute and ECG showed third degree AV block. Such a patient is best managed by:
questions.solution:
Administration of digiband which is an antibody against digoxin will be the most appropriate answer. 

A hemodyanamically unstable patient with 3rd degree heart block and bradycardia is presentation of digoxin toxicity. 
Aspect Details
What is Digibind? A digoxin-specific antibody used to treat digoxin toxicity.
Indications - Severe digoxin toxicity- Life-threatening arrhythmias- Significant overdose- Hyperkalemia (high potassium)
Mechanism of Action Binds to free digoxin in the bloodstream, forming a complex that is excreted in urine, neutralizing its effects.
Administration Intravenous (IV), dose based on digoxin levels and toxicity severity.
Side Effects - Rare allergic reactions (rash, anaphylaxis)- Hypokalemia (low potassium)
Monitoring Monitor ECG, serum potassium, and digoxin levels.
Duration Half-life: 20-30 hours; may need re-administration for severe cases.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 556, 558, 560, 561.

questions.text: A known case of depressive illness consumed large number of TCA tablets and presented to the Emergency Department with altered sensorium, dryness of mouth, sweating, postural hypotension and urinary retention. ECG was done which showed wide QRS complex. An important step in management of such a patient:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of TCA toxicity. The drug of choice for TCA overdose is sodium bicarbonate. 


Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 62, 158, 271, 273, 276.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1924, 3587.

questions.text: A female suffering from carcinoma of ovary was started on Cisplatin. Later on, she presented to the Emergency department with the complaints of several episodes of vomiting. She was given anti-emetic drug, which resulted in the development of muscle dystonia. Which anti-emetic drug was probably given?
questions.solution:
The female has developed extrapyramidal adverse effect in the form of muscle dystonia. It occurs due to antagonist action on dopamine receptors in central nervous system by metoclopramide which has a property to cross blood brain barrier. 


Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 18, 156, 923, 942.

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 712-717.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice in over dosage of paracetamol?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for paracetamol poisoning is N-acetylcysteine. 
 
  • Acetaminophen is an important cause of acute liver failure.
  • It is metabolized by cytochrome P450 CYP 2E1 which converts acetaminophen to N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone-imine ( NAPQ1 ).
  • Glutathione is responsible for its detoxification.
  • Depletion of glutathione results in excessive production of NAPQ1 which causes acute liver necrosis. 
 
  • N-acetylcysteine helps in replenishment of glutathione. 



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 198, 241, 452-454.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2586, 2588, 2589, 2623, 2627.

questions.text: Which of the following drug does NOT affect pleura?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, metformin is not associated with pleural pathology. 
 
  • The side effects of metformin are as follows-  Gastrointestinal disturbances (Most common) , lactic acidosis, vitamin B12 deficiency. 
 
  • The drugs given in the remaining options do cause pulmonary fibrosis. 



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 190, 298, 299, 809, 810, 927.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3110, 3111.

questions.text: A patient of deep venous thrombosis was started on some anticoagulant drug, but after 5 days, he developed some lesion over the toes. Clinical image is shown below. Which of the following drug is responsible for such a presentation?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is suggestive of purple toe syndrome. It is an adverse reaction of warfarin. 
 
  • It occurs due to cholesterol microemboli which are released from atheromatous plaques. These emboli will cause arterial occlusion. 
  • It is an indication to stop warfarin and replace with oral factor Xa inhibitor- apixaban, rivaroxaban. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 663, 665, 670-672.

Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 592-594.

choices.text: Inhibition of synthesis of mycolic acid in bacterial cell wall

questions.text: A young male with urinary tract infection was given some antimicrobial agent. This agent has the tendency of causing arthropathy in children and causing tendon repture. What is the mechanism of this antimicrobial drug given to the patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the male has been given fluoroquinolone which has an adverse effect profile of causing tendon rupture and arthropathy. 

It works by inhibiting DNA gyrase. 



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 760, 761, 766, 784.

Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 1015, 1017.

questions.text: A patient presented with rice water stools. Which of the ganglioside receptors is affected?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario of passage of rice water stools is suggestive of cholera.
 
  • It is caused by Vibrio Cholerae which shows characteristic darting motility. 
 
  • It produces an enterotoxin which binds to GM1 ganglioside receptor in jejunum.
  • This results in persistent activation of cAMP which causes massive secretion of water and electrolytes causing watery diarrhea. 



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 309, 313, 314.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1307, 1308.

questions.text: Which of the following microfilaria has a sheath surrounding it and had two big nuclei at the tail tip?
questions.solution:
The organism based on the given description is Brugia Malayi. 

The microfilariae of B. Malayi are sheathed with kinks and secondary curves. The tail tip has two nuclei and the organism shows nocturnal periodicity. 
 
  • Option 2- Microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti are sheathed with absent nuclei at tail tip. It shows nocturnal periodicity.
 
  • Option 3-  Microfilariae of onchocerca are unsheathed and nuclei do not extend till tail tip. 
 
  • Option 4- Loa Loa's microfilariae are sheathed and nuclei are arranged in a row upto the tail tip.


Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8the edition, Page no 208-211.

questions.text: A woodworker developed a chronic localized lesion over the legs. The lesion was irregular and cauliflower like. Histopathology of the lesion showed the presence of 'copper penny' as shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with histopathological finding of copper penny/sclerotic bodies is suggestive of Chromoblastoycosis.
 

Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal skin infection caused by pigmented fungi found in soil and decaying plant material, prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions. It occurs when fungi enter through minor skin injuries.

  • Symptoms: Starts as small warty lesions that grow into larger, nodular, or crusted plaques over time. Lesions may lead to disfigurement but are typically painless.
 
  • Diagnosis: Identified through microscopy (Copper-penny bodies or Medlar bodies or Sclerotic bodies), fungal culture, or biopsy.
 
  • Treatment:
    • Antifungals like itraconazole or terbinafine.
    • Physical therapies like cryotherapy or surgical excision for localized lesions.
 
  • Prevention: Wear protective gear during outdoor activities in endemic areas and promptly treat skin injuries.

Although slow-progressing, early treatment significantly improves outcomes.




Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1666, 1688-1692.

questions.text: A truck driver, who is a known case of HIV-1 develops sudden onset of breathlessness, fever and lymph node enlargement. There was pleural effusion as well. His vitals were stable. Culture showed a dimorphic fungi with mold form at 25 degrees C and yeast form at 37 degrees C. Colonies show red pigmentation. What is the likely causative agent and drug used for treatment?

  • On HPE, it shows yeast like organisms with central septation.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered best for diagnosing HIV infection in a baby born to an HIV infected mother?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of HIV in a newborn baby born to an HIV-infected mother is done using a polymerase chain reaction. Antibody, ELISA are not used due to maternal transmission causing false-positivity.

Recommended testing:
  • HIV DNA or RNA PCR should be performed at birth, 1–2 months, and 4–6 months in high-risk infants.
  • A definitive diagnosis is made when two separate PCR tests are positive.

Other options:
 
  • Detection of HIV-antibodies in neonate: Not reliable because maternal HIV antibodies can cross the placenta and persist in the infant’s circulation for up to 18 months, even if the baby is not infected.
  • PCR: Detects HIV DNA or RNA and is the most sensitive and specific method for diagnosing HIV infection in neonates. It can identify the virus directly, even in the presence of maternal antibodies.
  • ELISA: Not suitable for neonates for the same reason as antibody detection — it primarily detects antibodies, which may be maternal in origin.
  • p24 antigen: Has lower sensitivity in neonates and is not as reliable as PCR for early diagnosis.


Reference: Essenrial Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 228, 229.

questions.text: Leading questions are permitted in:
questions.solution:
Leading questions are allowed in cross -examination. 
 
  • As per section 141 of Indian Evidence Act, a leading question is one which is suggestive of the answer that s desired or one which includes a fact and leads to admitting of a conclusive answer in the form of yes or no.
 
  • Leading questions are allowed in:
1. Cross examination

2. Hostile witness

questions.text: A 10 years old boy presented to the Emergency department with vomiting. Parents said that he had consumed 15 tablets of ferrous sulphate. Which drug should be used in such a patient?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is  suggestive of iron toxicity due to consumption of FeSO4 talets.
 
  • It is managed by administration of an iron chelator which among the given options is Option 3-Desferrioxamine.
 

Iron toxicity occurs when there is excessive iron in the body, leading to oxidative damage and cellular injury. It can be acute (from overdose) or chronic (from conditions like hemochromatosis).

Causes:

  • Acute: Accidental ingestion (common in children) or intentional overdose.
  • Chronic: Repeated blood transfusions, hereditary hemochromatosis, or excessive dietary supplementation.
Clinical phases of Acute toxicity:
 
  1. Gastrointestinal Stage (0–6 hours): Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and hematemesis. Severe cases may show hypovolemic shock.
  2. Latent Phase (6–24 hours): Temporary resolution of symptoms, potentially masking ongoing systemic damage.
  3. Shock/Metabolic Stage (6–72 hours): Multiorgan failure, acidosis, hypotension, liver injury, coagulopathy, and hypoglycemia.
  4. Hepatic Stage (2–5 days): Fulminant liver failure, coagulopathy, and encephalopathy.
  5. Recovery Stage (2–4 weeks): Resolution with potential long-term complications like strictures in the gastrointestinal tract.
Mechanism: 

Excess iron generates reactive oxygen species (ROS), causing oxidative stress and damage to cellular structures, particularly in the liver, heart, and gastrointestinal tract.

Diagnosis

  • Elevated serum iron levels (>300–500 µg/dL).
  • Increased anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Radiographic imaging may show radiopaque iron tablets in the stomach.
  • Evidence of liver dysfunction (elevated ALT/AST).
Management:
  1. Decontamination:
    • Gastric lavage (if ingestion is recent).
    • Whole bowel irrigation for significant ingestion.
  2. Supportive Care:
    • IV fluids, correction of metabolic acidosis, and management of shock.
  3. Chelation Therapy:
    • Deferoxamine: Binds free iron and facilitates its excretion in urine.
  4. Severe Cases:
    • Consider dialysis for iron chelate removal if deferoxamine fails.
    • Monitor for liver and cardiac complications.
Prognosis
  • Prompt treatment improves outcomes.
  • Delayed care or severe cases may lead to death or permanent organ damage.



Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 548.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2343, 2588, 2847, 3236.

questions.text: A 50 years old male presented with loss of hairs of head and loss of eyebrows. His wife said that he is also having some behavioural changes. Doctor looked at the nail to reach up to the diagnosis. Poisoning is most probably due to:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hair loss, loss of eyebrows with behavioral and nail changes goes in favour of thallium poisoning. 

Hair loss characteristically involves lateral thirds of the eyebrows. Mees lines are seen in nails.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of fatigue, constipation, headache, insomnia and joint pains. He is working in a pain factory since last 20 years. Blood test revealed anemia. Which enzyme is affected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic lead poisoning and the enzyme affected in this case is option 4- aminolevulinic acid dehydratase or ALA dehydratase. 

The other key enzyme of heme metabolism pathway inhibited by lead is ferrochelatase. 
 

The patient's symptoms (fatigue, constipation, headache, insomnia, joint pains) along with anemia and long-term exposure in a paint factory suggest lead poisoning. Lead poisoning inhibits key enzymes involved in the heme synthesis pathway, particularly:

  1. ALA dehydratase (delta-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase):
    • Lead directly inhibits this enzyme, leading to the accumulation of ALA (delta-aminolevulinic acid) in the blood and urine.
    • This contributes to anemia and neurological symptoms.
  2. Ferrochelatase (not listed as an option):
    • Lead also inhibits ferrochelatase, causing the accumulation of protoporphyrin in red blood cells.
Other options: 
 
  1. Uroporphyrinogen I synthase: Associated with acute intermittent porphyria, not lead poisoning.
  2. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase: Deficiency causes congenital erythropoietic porphyria, unrelated to lead exposure.
  3. ALA synthase: This enzyme is regulated by heme levels but is not directly inhibited by lead.



Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 544, 545.

questions.text: A doctor was drunk and he performed a major surgery on a patient. Mistakenly he injured a major artery and the patient died. This is an example of:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of criminal negligence on the part of doctor. 

Criminal negligence is when a doctor lacks a gross skill or care while treating causing serious injury/death of the patient. 

Most of the cases occur due to drunkenness or usage of drugs. 
 
  • Criminal negligence involves gross negligence or reckless disregard for the safety of others, leading to serious harm or death.
  • In this case, the doctor performed surgery while intoxicated, which is an act of reckless behavior and a severe deviation from the standard of care, leading to the patient's death. This qualifies as criminal negligence.
Other options: 
 
  1. Dichotomy: Refers to an unethical practice where a physician receives a commission for referring patients, unrelated to this scenario.
  2. Therapeutic misadventure: Refers to an unintended and unavoidable adverse outcome of a medical procedure despite appropriate care. This does not apply here because the doctor's actions were reckless and preventable.
  3. Civil negligence: Involves failure to meet the standard of care, leading to harm. While this is also negligence, it is not "criminal" unless there is gross or willful misconduct, as in this case.


Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 40, 41, 46, 646.

questions.text: A doctor explained the benefits and risks of doing a surgical procedure to the patient. After that the patient signed the consent form. This is known as:
questions.solution:
• In the given clinical scenario, the patient has been made aware of the benefits an complications of the procedure to which the patient has agreed. 
 
  • This is an example of informed consent.
 
  • Informed consent occurs when a healthcare provider explains the nature of a medical procedure, including its benefits, risks, and alternatives, and the patient voluntarily agrees to proceed, often by signing a consent form. This process ensures the patient understands and consents to the procedure based on adequate information.
     

Other options:

  • Implied consent: This is assumed in situations where consent is not explicitly given, such as in emergencies when a patient is unconscious and unable to provide consent.
  • Therapeutic privilege: This refers to a situation where a doctor withholds information from a patient if disclosing it could cause harm to the patient's mental or physical health.
  • Informed refusal: This happens when a patient, after being informed of the benefits and risks, chooses to decline the procedure.

In the scenario described, the patient was informed and willingly signed the consent form, indicating informed consent.




Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 50, 51.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of WHO STEP wise approach?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, psychological measurement is not a component of WHO STEP wise approach. 

STEP approach of WHO is a survey methodology developed to assess risk factors of non communicable diseases. It includes:
 
  1. Questionnaires containing questions regarding behavioral risk factor like tobacco use. 
  2. Physical measurements in the form of blood pressure, height, weight. 
  3. Biochemical methods in the form of blood glucose, lipids. 

Mental health and suicide may be included in optional behavioral risk factors but it is the least preferrable option among others.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 47, 287, 373, 394, 452.

questions.text: You are posted at an urban PHC. You received 1 open vial of pentavalent vaccine and 1 open vial of MMR vaccine after 2 days of a vaccination drive. Cold chain requirements were fully met. What will you do ?
questions.solution:
According to open vial policy, MMR vaccine once reconstituted should not be reused. Hence, it is discarded. 

On the other hand, Pentavalent vaccine follows open vial policy and therefore can be reused upto 28 days.
 

In immunization programs, open vial policies (OVP) guide whether a vaccine vial can be used after being opened, provided certain conditions are met. These conditions include adherence to the cold chain, proper handling, and sterility. According to the World Health Organization (WHO) and national guidelines:

  1. Pentavalent vaccine (DTP-HepB-Hib):

    • It is a liquid vaccine, and if stored properly (cold chain maintained at 2–8°C) and sterility is ensured, it can be used for up to 28 days after opening as per the multi-dose vial policy.

  2. MMR vaccine (Measles, Mumps, Rubella):

    • This is a lyophilized (powdered) vaccine that requires reconstitution with a diluent before use. Once reconstituted, it must be used within 6 hours or discarded, as it is more prone to contamination and loses potency rapidly.


Appropriate action: Since the MMR vial has been open for 2 days, it must be discarded. The pentavalent vaccine, if stored properly and meeting the multi-dose vial policy, can still be used.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 121.

choices.text: Children from the same community, not having blood cancer, not exposed to water
Children from the same community, not having blood cancer, exposed to water
Children from the hospital, not having blood cancer, not exposed to water

questions.text: Number of children from a particular community were found to have blood cancer. It was presumed that there is some chemical in the water supplied that might have caused the blood cancer. It was decided to conduct a case-control study to find the association of this chemical with the occurrence of blood cancer. Children having ALL and exposed to water was taken as cases. What group of children will constitute control?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, children who belong to same community and not suffering from blood cancer as well as not exposed to water can be taken as controls. 
 
  • Children from the community who do not have the disease will be considered as the control group for the case-control study. The key criterion for selecting a control group is that they must be free from the disease being studied. They should closely resemble the cases in all aspects except for the absence of the disease.
 
  • Typically, the control group consists of individuals who have not been exposed to the disease or the factor being investigated. Hence, the best option for this study is to use children attending the OPD without the disease and without exposure as the controls.
 
  • Case-control studies, also known as retrospective studies, work by tracing the effect back to its cause and are conducted after both exposure and outcome have occurred. These studies focus on health issues or diseases that have already developed. They are less time-intensive and avoid the risk of attrition since follow-up is not required.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 79-83.

questions.text:
You are posted as a Medical Officer in a PHC in a seismic area. To handle emergencies, which of the following actions will you take? 
A. Preparedness to handle any emergency 
B. Ensure resources and funds are available for quick mobilization at the time of emergency 
C. Disaster simulation programs 
D. Give instructions over loudspeakers

1- A,B,C,D
2-B,C,D
3-A,B,C
4-A,B,D
questions.solution:
Steps 1,2 and 3 are done as part of preparedness for an emergency in a high seismic zone. 

Giving instructions over phone is done when the emergency strikes and not a part disaster preparedness.
 

To handle emergencies effectively in a seismic area, the following actions are essential:

  • Preparedness to handle any emergency (A): Being ready with plans, protocols, and resources to address emergencies is crucial in such high-risk areas.
  • Ensure resources and funds are available for quick mobilization (B): Proper allocation of resources and funds ensures a swift response when emergencies occur.
  • Disaster simulation programs (C): Regular training and simulation exercises help staff and the community stay prepared for real-life scenarios.
 

While giving instructions over loudspeakers (D) might be useful during an actual disaster, it is not a key preparatory action. Hence, it is not included in the best choice for overall emergency readiness.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 926, 927.

choices.text: Give injection Benzathine penicillin for 5 years or until the age of 18 years, whichever is later
Give injection Benzathine penicillin for 10 years or until the age of 25 years, whichever is later

questions.text: A 12 years old girl is suffering has clinical manifestations of rheumatic fever. She had no carditis.Which of the following is true regarding secondary prevention?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. The secondary prophylaxis  after an episode for a patient who weighs less than 27 kg is 6,00,000 IU of benzathine penicillin once in 3 weeks for 5 years or till the age of 18, whichever is longer. 
 
  • Secondary prevention of rheumatic fever involves the use of prophylactic antibiotics to prevent recurrent attacks, which can lead to rheumatic heart disease.
  • In a patient with rheumatic fever but no carditis, the recommended duration of secondary prophylaxis is 5 years or until 18 years of age, whichever is later.
  • Injection Benzathine penicillin G (1.2 million units intramuscular every 3–4 weeks) is the standard regimen for secondary prophylaxis.


Other options 

  • Option 2 is applicable for patients with carditis and residual heart disease.
  • Option 3 (lifelong prophylaxis) is used in special cases, such as those with severe valve disease or after valve surgery.
  • Option 4 (single dose) is inadequate for secondary prevention.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 433. 434.

questions.text: An army recruit presented with myalgia, fever and rashes. There were no rashes on palms and soles. Many soldiers from his battalion were found to be infested with louse. What could be the causative organism related to his clinical condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of epidemic or louse borne typhus which is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. 
 
  • Rickettsia prowazekii causes epidemic typhus, a disease transmitted by the human body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis).
  • Epidemic typhus typically presents with fever, myalgia, and a maculopapular rash, which commonly spares the palms and soles.
  • The context of many soldiers being infested with lice strongly suggests a louse-borne illness.
 

Other options:

  • Rickettsia typhi: Causes endemic (murine) typhus, which is transmitted by fleas, not lice.
  • Rickettsia tsutsugamushi: Causes scrub typhus, which is transmitted by chiggers (mite larvae) and is more common in rural and scrubland areas.
  • Rickettsia conorii: Causes Mediterranean spotted fever, transmitted by dog ticks, and its rash often involves the palms and soles.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 414.

Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th edition, Page no 358, 359.

choices.text: Removing stray dogs and vaccinating all pet-dogs
Administer Rabies vaccine to the general population

questions.text: Which of the following is a cost-effective and rational approach for controlling Rabies in an urban area?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the most cost effective and rational approach for controlling rabies is to reduce the stray dog population and vaccinating all pet dogs. 

Rabies is caused by Lyssavirus type 1 and carries a mortality rate of ~100%. 
 
  • Testing all the dogs for Rabies: This is not practical or cost-effective because rabies testing requires euthanizing animals for laboratory diagnosis. Testing every dog is neither scalable nor humane.
  • Increase lab facilities: While this can improve rabies diagnostics, it is not a direct or cost-effective measure for controlling rabies. Priority should be given to prevention (dog vaccination and population management) over expanded lab facilities.
  • Removing stray dogs and vaccinating all pet dogs: This approach addresses the primary source of rabies transmission—unvaccinated dogs. Vaccinating at least 70% of the dog population (both stray and pet) is the cornerstone of rabies control, as dogs are the main reservoir of the virus in urban areas.
  • Administer Rabies vaccine to the general population: This is unnecessary and prohibitively expensive. Providing post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) to those bitten by potentially rabid animals is a more cost-effective and rational alternative.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 302, 303, 307.

questions.text: Average life span of women in Japan is 84 years. Due to recent advances in testing for cervical cancer, there is an increase in life expectancy by 15 years. The healthcare utility value is 0.8. Which of the following can be calculated from the parameters given?
questions.solution:
QALY can be calculated from utility value. 

It is a disability rate indicator and based on the number of years that would be added to life due to medical intervention. 
 

  • HALE (Health-Adjusted Life Expectancy):
    This measures life expectancy adjusted for time spent in less than perfect health. While the healthcare utility value (0.8) might contribute to calculating HALE, the increase in life expectancy by 15 years does not directly indicate time spent in less than optimal health.

  • QALY (Quality-Adjusted Life Years):
    QALY combines the quantity and quality of life. It is calculated by multiplying the additional years of life expectancy by the quality of life (utility value).

    • Formula:
       QALY=Additional life years × Utility value
      • Here, QALY=15×0.8=12
        This can be directly calculated from the given data.

  • DALY (Disability-Adjusted Life Years):
    This measures the burden of disease by combining years of life lost (YLL) and years lived with disability (YLD). The provided information does not include data on years lost or disability weights, so DALY cannot be calculated.

  • DFLE (Disability-Free Life Expectancy):
    This is the average number of years a person can expect to live without disability. It requires specific data about disability prevalence or burden, which is not provided in the question.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no  26.

questions.text:
Which of the following points are correct regarding 'At-Risk' infant?

(i) Birth weight less than 2.5 kg 
(ii) Birth order of more than 3 
(iii) Single parent 
(iv) Artificial feeding 
(v) Birth weight of <85 percentile
questions.solution:
Among the given options, birth weight less than 2.5 kg, single parent and artificial feeding are considered at-risk infants.

Birth order of 5 or more (not more than 3) and weight < 70% (not < 85 percentile) of the expected weight are also considered at-risk infants. 

Criteria of At-risk infants:
 
  • Low birth weight (<2.5 kg)
  • Twins
  • High birth order (5 or more)
  • Artificial feeding
  • Severe malnutrition (weight <70% of expected, indicating Grade II or III malnutrition).
  • Failure to gain weight over 3 consecutive months.
  • Protein-energy malnutrition (PEM) combined with diarrhea.
  • Working mothers or single parents.

Significance:

Recognizing these infants is essential because they significantly contribute to perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality rates. Early identification enables targeted interventions and intensive care to improve their survival and long-term health outcomes.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no  587.

choices.text: Look through the mouth to see if any foreign body is there

questions.text: A young male was having his lunch in a hotel. Suddenly he started having breathlessness as shown in the figure.What should be done?
questions.solution:
The next step in the given scenario is to perform Heimlich's maneuver.
 
  • It is also known as subdiaphragmatic abdominal thrusts and is done primarily for adults and children between 1-8 years of age with foreign body causing airway obstruction. 
 
  • If the patient becomes unconscious or unresponsive, the next best step is to immediately begin cardiopulmonary resuscitation. 


Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 7th edition, Page no 367.

questions.text: A 15 years old male presented to ENT OPD with complaints of unilateral nasal blockage and recurrent epistaxis.He is alos having hearing loss. On local examination, a pink mass was seen obstructing the choana, as shown in the image below. Contrast CT scan enhanced uptake of contrast. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with recurrent epistaxis and unilateral nasal blockade with contrast enhanced CT showing a growth along with trans-nasal endoscopic image goes in favor of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.
 
  • It is a benign but locally aggressive tumor seen in adolescent males.
  • It arises from posterior part of nasal cavity near the region of sphenopalatine foramen. \
 
  • Investigation of choice- Contrast enhanced CT scan. ( Biopsy is contraindicated )
  • Staging system used- Radkowski 
 
  • Treatment- Surgical approach is the treatment of choice. Embolisation of vessels can be done prior to surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding during surgery.
  • Radiotherapy, Chemotherapy and hormonal therapy can also be considered.


Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 7th edition, Page no 153, 175, 193, 279-281.

questions.text: A known case of asthma presented to the ENT OPD with the complaints of chronic rhinorrhoea and nasal polyps. After evaluation, a diagnosis of Samter's triad was made. Which drug should be AVOIDED in such a patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with Samter's triad, aspirin should be avoided. 
 

Samter's Triad (also known as Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease, or AERD) is characterized by:

  1. Asthma
  2. Chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps
  3. Sensitivity to aspirin and other NSAIDs

In patients with Samter's Triad, taking aspirin or other NSAIDs that inhibit cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) can trigger severe respiratory reactions, including bronchospasm, nasal congestion, or even life-threatening asthma attacks.

Other options:

  • Co-amoxiclav, penicillin, and cotrimoxazole are antibiotics and do not act on the COX pathway, so they do not pose the same risk as aspirin.

Management:
 
  • Avoid all COX-1 inhibiting NSAIDs.
  • Acetaminophen (paracetamol) is usually safe but should be used cautiously in sensitive individuals.


Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 7th edition, Page no 193, 194.

questions.text: A 6 years old child was brought to the ENT OPD with the complaints of hearing loss, earache and delayed speech. Otoscopic examination findings are shown below in the image. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with hearing loss, earache and delayed speech with otoscopic findings of a dull tympanic membrane with fluid levels and air bubbles goes in favor of otitis media with effusion. 
 

Otitis Media with Effusion (OME), also known as glue ear, is the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs of infection. It is common in children and may lead to hearing loss and speech delays if untreated.

Cause:

  • Eustachian tube dysfunction (most common).
  • Upper respiratory infections, allergies, and environmental factors like passive smoking.
  • Anatomical issues such as cleft palate.
Symptoms: 
  • Hearing loss (most common).
  • Fullness or pressure in the ear.
  • Rare balance problems.

Diagnosis:
  • Physical exam (otoscopy shows fluid behind the eardrum).
  • Tympanometry to assess middle ear pressure.
  • Audiometry to detect hearing loss.

Management: 
  • Observation: Many cases resolve on their own within 3 months.
  • Surgical: Tympanostomy tube placement for persistent cases or significant hearing loss.
  • Medical: Decongestants and antihistamines may help, but antibiotics are generally not recommended.

Complications: 
  • Persistent hearing loss affecting language development.
  • Recurrent ear infections or cholesteatoma (rare).
Prevention: 
  • Minimize exposure to smoke and allergens, practice good hygiene, and encourage breastfeeding.

OME typically resolves on its own, but persistent cases require monitoring and possible treatment to avoid complications like hearing loss.



Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 7th edition, Page no 58, 67, 69-71.

choices.text: Use of flexible bronchoscope is indicated in management
If there is decreased air entry on right side, it suggests foreign body
In complete obstruction, Ball valve effect is the mechanism responsible for hyperinflation of right lung
Clinical diagnosis is of croup is made

questions.text: A 3years old child presented to the emergency department with difficulty in breathing. Chest X-ray was done and it showed hyperinflation of right side, left side being normal. True statement related to this clinical picture:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is of aspirated foreign body. Among the given options, the correct statement is option 2.
 

Foreign bodies are more likely to enter the right bronchus because it is wider and more aligned with the tracheal lumen. The initial evaluation typically involves a plain chest X-ray in posteroanterior and lateral views, with expiratory films being particularly useful. These may reveal:

  • The size, shape, and location of a radio-opaque foreign body.
  • In cases of complete airway obstruction, lobar or segmental atelectasis.
  • In incomplete airway obstruction, the ball valve mechanism occurs when a foreign body partially blocks a bronchus, allowing air to enter but not exit. This results in hyperinflation or obstructive emphysema of the affected area, particularly visible on expiratory X-ray films as trapped air cannot escape.

Management of airway foreign bodies includes:

  • Laryngeal foreign bodies: The Heimlich maneuver should be attempted first. If unsuccessful, cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy may be necessary.
  • Foreign bodies in the trachea or bronchi: These are removed using a rigid bronchoscope after ensuring adequate hydration and gastric emptying.
  • Antibiotics are administered as needed to prevent secondary infections.



Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 7th edition, Page no 365-367.

Essential Pediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 368, 390.

questions.text: A patient with damage of basilar membrane presented with high frequency hearing loss. Most likely site of lesion:
questions.solution:
The affected structure in high frequency hearing loss is basal turn of cochlea. 

Among the given options, the structure present in close proximity to basal turn of cochlea is oval window. 

The basilar membrane in the cochlea is tonotopically organized:

  • The base of the basilar membrane (near the oval window) is stiff and narrow, making it sensitive to high-frequency sounds.
  • The apex of the basilar membrane (near the helicotrema) is wider and more flexible, making it sensitive to low-frequency sounds.

Damage to the basilar membrane near the oval window would impair the detection of high-frequency sounds, leading to high-frequency hearing loss.

Other options: 

  1. Stria vascularis: (Option 1)

    • Produces endolymph and maintains the ionic composition necessary for normal cochlear function. Damage here causes global cochlear dysfunction, not frequency-specific loss.

  2. Helicotrema: (Option 2)

    • Located at the apex of the cochlea, it is involved in low-frequency sound detection. Damage here would cause low-frequency hearing loss, not high-frequency.

  3. Modiolus: (Option 4)

    • The central bony core of the cochlea housing the spiral ganglion neurons. Damage here typically causes neural or sensorineural hearing loss rather than being frequency-specific.


Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 7th edition, Page no 10, 11, 17.

questions.text: Which nerve is possibly involved in a person presenting with headache, lacrimation and photophobia?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of headache, lacrimation and photophobia. the nerve most likely involved is trigeminal nerve. 
 

The trigeminal nerve (5th cranial nerve) is primarily responsible for sensory innervation of the face, including the eyes and surrounding structures. It also plays a role in some autonomic reflexes through its association with the parasympathetic fibers that mediate lacrimation.

A person presenting with headache, lacrimation, and photophobia could be experiencing conditions like:

  • Cluster headache: Often involves activation of the trigeminal autonomic pathways, leading to lacrimation, conjunctival injection, and photophobia.
  • Trigeminal neuralgia: Though less common with these symptoms, irritation of the trigeminal nerve could present with facial pain and autonomic symptoms.
  • Migraine: Trigeminal activation is involved in the pathophysiology of migraines, which can include photophobia and sometimes lacrimation.

Other options: 
 

  1. 6th CN (Abducens nerve):

    • Controls lateral eye movement (lateral rectus muscle). Dysfunction causes diplopia, not typically photophobia or lacrimation.

  2. 4th CN (Trochlear nerve):

    • Controls the superior oblique muscle for downward and inward eye movement. Dysfunction leads to vertical diplopia, not associated with headache, lacrimation, or photophobia.

  3. 3rd CN (Oculomotor nerve):

    • Controls most extraocular muscles and parasympathetic fibers for pupil constriction. Damage might cause ptosis and photophobia (due to a dilated pupil) but is not linked to lacrimation or trigeminal-mediated headache.

Thus, involvement of the trigeminal nerve (5th CN) is the most likely cause of these symptoms.



Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 7th edition, Page no 103-105.

questions.text: A patient had a history of penetrating trauma of the eye and a diagnosis of sympathetic ophthalmitis was made. Which of the following is seen?
questions.solution:
• The most common manifestation of sympathetic ophthalmitis is panuveitis- inflammation of the whole uvea. 
 
  • It is a granulomatous panuveitis which occurs following penetrating trauma/intraocular surgery. The injured eye ( exciting eye ) and fellow eye ( sympathizing eye ) develop panuveitis. 
 
  • It is an example of type 4 hypersensitivity reaction. 


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 155, 158-161.

questions.text: Such a treatment is carried out for:
questions.solution:
• The given image demonstrates INTACS, which is done for keratoconus.
 
  • Keratoconus, also known as conical cornea, is a non-inflammatory condition affecting the axial cornea.
  • It is characterized by central or paracentral thinning and apical protrusion of the anterior cornea, which are pathognomonic features.
  • This condition is associated with defects in mucopolysaccharide and collagen tissue synthesis.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 128, 135-137.

questions.text: Identify the vitamin deficiency associated with the image shown below:
questions.solution:
• The given image shows Bitot spots in temporal bulbar conjunctiva seen due to deficiency of vitamin A. 
 
  • They are white patches of keratinized epithelium on sclera, more commonly seen on temporal side. 
 
  • It is categorized in stage X1B of WHO grading of vitamin A deficiency. It is reversible on administration of vitamin A. 


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 488, 489.

questions.text: Identify the clinical condition:
questions.solution:
The image provided shows white, flaky material deposited on the anterior lens capsule and the pupillary margin, which is characteristic of Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome (PXF).

Features:

  • White, dandruff-like deposits are visible on the lens capsule and around the pupil.
  • This material is pathognomonic for PXF and can cause complications such as poor pupil dilation, zonular weakness, and glaucoma.
 
  • Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is an age-related condition that involves the deposition of fibrillary material in the anterior segment of the eye.
  • It increases the risk of secondary open-angle glaucoma and complications during cataract surgery due to zonular instability.



Reference: Parson's Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 273, 1270, 1271.

questions.text: A known case of Rheumatoid arthritis attended ophthalmology OPD with the complaints as shown in the image below. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows scleral thinning with protusion of uveal tissue through it. In a patient of rheumatoid arthritis, this diagnosis goes in favor of Scleromalacia perforans. 
 

Scleromalacia Perforans is a severe form of scleritis that occurs primarily in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), characterized by painless thinning and perforation of the sclera, typically in the inferior quadrant of the eye.

Pathophysiology: Immune-mediated inflammation leads to thinning and weakening of the sclera, without significant initial inflammation.

Clinical Features:
  • Asymptomatic in early stages.
  • Gradual thinning of the sclera, which may eventually lead to perforation.
  • Unlike typical scleritis, pain and redness may be minimal or absent in advanced stages.
Diagnosis: Based on clinical examination, with potential imaging (e.g., ultrasound, OCT) to assess scleral thinning and perforations.

Treatment: Primarily involves managing the underlying rheumatoid arthritis with immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., steroids, methotrexate, biologics). Surgical repair may be needed for scleral perforations.

Prognosis: Early detection and treatment can slow progression, but if untreated, it may lead to severe complications, including loss of the eye.

Scleromalacia perforans is a sight-threatening complication of rheumatoid arthritis that requires prompt and aggressive management to prevent irreversible damage.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 97, 147-149, 180, 183, 257, 398.

questions.text: A known case of diabetes mellitus had developed pre-retinal hemorrhage neovascularization of the disc. Such a case should be managed by:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of proliferative diabetic retinopathy and therefore, the next step in management is to perform a pan retinal photocoagulation. 
 
  • Neovascularization of the disc (NVD) and pre-retinal hemorrhage are signs of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR), a severe form of diabetic eye disease. In this stage, abnormal blood vessels (neovascularization) grow on the optic disc and elsewhere in the retina, which can lead to complications like retinal hemorrhages, retinal detachment, and vision loss.
  • Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the gold standard treatment for proliferative diabetic retinopathy. It involves applying laser to areas of the retina away from the macula to reduce the production of angiogenic factors (such as VEGF) that contribute to neovascularization. The goal of PRP is to prevent further neovascular growth and reduce the risk of complications like vitreous hemorrhage and retinal detachment.
Other options:
 
  1. Anti-VEGF drugs: These can be used in cases of macular edema or to treat neovascularization in specific cases, but for diffuse neovascularization like NVD, PRP is typically preferred.
  2. Grid photocoagulation by Laser: This is used for diabetic macular edema, not for proliferative diabetic retinopathy with neovascularization.
  3. Focal photocoagulation by Laser: This is used for localized areas of diabetic macular edema, not for neovascularization or widespread retinal involvement in PDR.

Therefore, pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the correct approach to manage this condition.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 285-287, 290, 291.

questions.text: A patient presented with a pituitary tumour with consequent overproduction of GH. He was planned for surgery but it was not possible to remove the entire tumour mass. What drug should be given to such patient to get maximum benefit?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of of pituitary tumor producing growth hormone will produce Acromegaly. The first line treatment of acromegaly is Octreotide.

It is a synthetic somatostatin analogue. 
 
  • The patient has a pituitary tumor causing overproduction of Growth Hormone (GH), leading to conditions such as acromegaly or gigantism.
  • Since surgery could not completely remove the tumor, pharmacological therapy is essential to control excess GH production.
  • Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, is highly effective at inhibiting GH secretion. It acts by binding to somatostatin receptors on the pituitary tumor, reducing both GH and Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IGF-1) levels, providing significant symptomatic relief and biochemical control.

Other options: 
 

  1. Bromocriptine: A dopamine agonist, sometimes used for GH-secreting tumors, but it is less effective compared to somatostatin analogs like octreotide. It is more commonly used for prolactinomas.

  2. Cabergoline: Another dopamine agonist, more potent than bromocriptine, but its role in GH-secreting tumors is secondary. It may be used if somatostatin analogs are not tolerated or as an adjunct.

  3. Goserelin: A gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist, used primarily for conditions like prostate cancer or endometriosis, with no role in treating GH-secreting pituitary tumors.



 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 260, 264.

Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 781, 932.

questions.text: A 40 years old patient presented with widening of teeth gaps, protrusion of chin, prominence of frontal bone, excessive sweating, impaired glucose tolerance and enlargement of the feet and hand. Which of the following is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of acromegaly.
Among the given options, Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat this condition. 

Other options:
 
  • Option 2- Octreotide is a synthetic analogue of somatostatin. It is used as first line in treatment of acromegaly. 
  • Option 3- Cabergoline is a D2 receptor agonist. It is used in treatment of hyperprolactinemia. 
  • Option 4- Bromocriptine is D2 receptor agonist used as a first line drug in treatment of hyperprolactinemia. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 260, 261.

questions.text: A patient presented to the Neurology OPD with the complaints of ballistic movements of arm. He had suffered stroke 6 moths back. What could be the probable site of lesion?

In the above clinical scenario, presence of ballistic movements of arm points to a diagnosis of hemiballismus and the site of lesion is the subthalamic nucleus.

questions.text: An elderly male patient with coronary artery disease presented with palpitations. His blood pressure was within normal range. ECG was done which is shown below. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
• The given case scenario goes in favor of diagnosis of ventricular tachycardia.
  • Intravenous amiodarone- a class III anti-arrhythmic drug is used in the management of this condition. 

Other options:
 
  • Option 1 and 2- Metoprolol is a selective B1 antagonist and class II antiarrhythmic drug. It is used in treatment of hypertension, angina and cardiac failure. 
  • Option 3- Oral amiodarone is used in chronic treatment of atrial and ventricular fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia.
