questions.text: An elderly patient with long presentation of hypertension attended Emergency department with the complaints of acute onset of breathlessness, anxiety and sweating. It was noticed that the patient was not taking anti-hypertensives regularly. On examination, respiratory rate was 20 breaths/minute. X-ray chest was done as shown below. Next step in managing such a case:
questions.solution:
The given case scenario along with CXR points towards acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to hypertension. Hence, the next best step in management will be administration of intravenous nitroglycerin in order to decrease blood pressure. 
  • Common causes include acute severe hypertension, acute myocardial infarction, or exacerbation of chronic heart failure.
  • Precipitating factors may involve medication non-compliance, excessive salt intake, or tachyarrhythmias.
 
  • The condition typically presents with severe dyspnea, pink frothy sputum, diaphoresis, and cyanosis.
  • On auscultation, rales and rhonchi are heard across all lung fields.
  • A chest X-ray reveals increased interstitial markings, vascular redistribution, and alveolar edema in a butterfly pattern, with cardiomegaly potentially present in chronic heart failure cases.
 
  • Management includes diuretics, nitrates, and morphine to reduce preload.
  • Nitroglycerin and isosorbide dinitrate, with their rapid onset of action, can be administered sublingually or intravenously if pulmonary edema persists and hypotension is absent.
  • Oxygen therapy is advised to maintain saturation above 92%.
  • If oxygen saturation remains inadequate, positive-pressure ventilation through a face mask or endotracheal intubation is necessary.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 355, 1930-1936.

questions.text:
A chronic smoker presented with difficulty in breathing. His artificial blood gas analysis revealed a pH of 7.2, PO2 of 70 mm Hg,
PCO2 of 80 mm Hg and HCO3 of 34 mEq. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given blood gas analysis suggests a diagnosis of respiratory acidosis due to elevated levels of pCO2 and an acidic pH. 
 

The patient’s arterial blood gas (ABG) findings are consistent with chronic respiratory acidosis with partial metabolic compensation. Here's the analysis:

  • pH of 7.2: Indicates acidemia (normal pH: 7.35–7.45).
  • PCO2 of 80 mm Hg: Significantly elevated, pointing to hypercapnia due to hypoventilation, which is the hallmark of respiratory acidosis.
  • HCO3 of 34 mEq/L: Elevated, reflecting renal compensation (attempt to counteract the acidosis by retaining bicarbonate).
  • PO2 of 70 mm Hg: Decreased, suggesting hypoxemia, commonly seen in chronic respiratory disorders.


Likely cause: The patient's history of chronic smoking points to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or another chronic respiratory condition that causes impaired gas exchange and CO2 retention, leading to respiratory acidosis.

Other options:

  1. Respiratory alkalosis: Characterized by high pH and low PCO2, opposite of the findings here.
  2. Metabolic alkalosis: High pH and elevated HCO3, not consistent with the patient’s acidemia.
  3. Metabolic acidosis: Low pH with decreased HCO3, which is not the case here.

Thus, the patient’s findings are best explained by respiratory acidosis due to chronic respiratory disease.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 359-361.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic male presented with bloody nasal discharge and hemifacial pain on left side with loosening of teeth from upper jaw on the left side. He is a follow-up case of COVID-19. Which of the following test would help in reaching upto a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given case scenario goes in favor of mucormycosis. 
 
  • Nasal swab and subsequent microbiological examination will help in arriving at diagnosis of mucormycosis.
  • It will show broad based aseptate hyphae with obtuse angle branching. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1682-1684.

questions.text:
A child presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain, vomiting and oliguria for the last 8 days. On examination, he was found to be dehydrated. Serum potassium and uric acid was raised. Peripheral smear showed the presence of
lymphoblasts. Immediate management of such a patient would be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with laboratory investigations are suggestive of Tumor lysis syndrome. 

The next best step of management will be aggressive hydration. 

Cairo-Bishop criteria is used to assess severity of TLS.

MANAGEMENT OF TLS:

Prevention:
 
  • Identify high-risk patients: Those with high tumor burden (e.g., Burkitt lymphoma, acute leukemia), rapidly proliferating tumors, or pre-existing kidney dysfunction.
  • Hydration:
    • Aggressive intravenous hydration (e.g., 3 L/m²/day) to maintain adequate urine output (>100 mL/m²/hour) and promote renal clearance of uric acid, phosphate, and potassium.
    • Avoid potassium-containing fluids.
  • Allopurinol:
    • A xanthine oxidase inhibitor to reduce the formation of uric acid from purines.
    • Dose: 300 mg/day, started 1–2 days before chemotherapy.
  • Rasburicase (recombinant urate oxidase):
    • Converts uric acid to allantoin (water-soluble and excretable).
    • Used in patients with high uric acid levels or at high risk of TLS.
    • Dose: 0.1–0.2 mg/kg IV once daily.
  • Electrolyte monitoring:
    • Frequent monitoring of potassium, phosphate, calcium, uric acid, and creatinine (every 6–12 hours in high-risk patients).

Treatment:
 
  • Hyperkalemia:
    • Immediate interventions if potassium >6.0 mmol/L or with ECG changes (e.g., peaked T waves, widened QRS).
    • Measures include:
      • Calcium gluconate (stabilizes myocardium).
      • Insulin with glucose or β-agonists (shifts potassium into cells).
      • Sodium bicarbonate (if acidosis is present).
      • Potassium binders or dialysis for refractory cases.
  • Hyperphosphatemia:
    • Restrict dietary phosphate intake.
    • Administer oral phosphate binders (e.g., sevelamer).
    • Dialysis if severe and unresponsive.
  • Hypocalcemia:
    • Treat only if symptomatic (e.g., tetany, arrhythmias) to avoid calcium-phosphate precipitation.
    • Administer IV calcium gluconate cautiously.
  • Hyperuricemia:
    • Rasburicase (preferred for rapid uric acid reduction).
    • Allopurinol to prevent further uric acid formation.
  • Acute Kidney Injury:
    • Optimize hydration and treat metabolic disturbances.
    • Initiate renal replacement therapy (dialysis) in severe cases.

Indication of Dialysis in TLS:
 
  • Severe hyperkalemia refractory to treatment.
  • Symptomatic hypocalcemia.
  • Severe hyperphosphatemia.
  • Volume overload or uncontrolled AKI.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 573, 574.

questions.text: A known case of chronic liver disease with ascites had a fever, abdominal pain, tenderness and reduced bowel sounds. Ascitic fluid analysis showed >250 polymorphs/cu mm. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of abdominal distension, fever with ascites, abdominal pain and tenderness with reduced bowel activity and ascitic neutrophil count of > 250 per mm3 is diagnostic of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. 
 
  • It is an acute infection of ascitic fluid. Most common organism implicated is E.Coli. 
 
  • Diagnosis is by paracentesis and an ascitic fluid neutrophil count of > 250/mm3. 
 
  • Drug of choice for treatment is third generation cephalosporins. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1054, 1055.

questions.text: A young patient presented to the Emergency with the complaint of palpitation. On palpation, pulse, was weak and irregularly irregular. There was a pulse deficit of 20 beats per minute. Blood pressure was normal and heart rate was 120 beats/minute. Jugular venous pulse in this patient will show:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario goes in favor of atrial fibrillation and it is characterized by absence of a wave on JVP. 

Other options: 
 
  • Option 1- Canon a wave is seen in atrioventricular dissociation. 
  • Option 3- Giant a wave is seen in right ventricular hypertrophy and pulmonary artery hypertension.
  • Option 4- Prominent v waves are seen in tricuspid regurgitation. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1817, 1874, 1903-1906.

choices.text: Intravenous fluid bolus in first hour with regular insulin after that
Intravenous fluid in first hour with long-acting insulin after that

questions.text: A known case of diabetes mellitus presented to the Emergency department with complaints of nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain. She is having altered sensorium. Attendants said that she never took medications regularly. General examination shoed that she is dehydrated. She was having tachycardia and systolic BP was 92 mm Hg. Her serum glucose was more than 500 mg/dl. Urine showed presence of sugar and ketone bodies. Best step in managing such a case:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario goes in favor of diabetic ketoacidosis and the next best step in management will be intravenous fluids with regular insulin. 
 

The patient is presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a life-threatening complication of diabetes mellitus characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis.

  1. Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, altered sensorium.
  2. Signs: Dehydration, tachycardia, hypotension.
  3. Laboratory:
    • Serum glucose >500 mg/dL (severe hyperglycemia).
    • Urine positive for sugar and ketones (ketonuria indicates ketosis).
    • Likely metabolic acidosis (though pH is not provided).

Management of  Diabetic Ketoacidosis:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 361, 1682, 3114-3116.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, jaundice and calf muscle tenderness. On examination, there was conjunctival suffusion and maculopapular eruptions on the trunk.Per abdomen examination revealed tender hepatomegaly. Blood test showed thrombocytopenia and raised bilirubin level. AST and ALT are moderately raised. Kidney function test is normal. Urine microscopy showed hematuria. Most diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario is leptospirosis. 

It is a zoonotic infection caused by Leptospira. It presents with fever with chills, conjunctival effusion, myalgia pronounced in calves, abdomen and back. 

Clinical features:
 
  1. Fever, jaundice, and calf muscle tenderness: Classic triad for severe leptospirosis.
  2. Conjunctival suffusion: Redness of the conjunctiva without exudate is a hallmark of leptospirosis.
  3. Maculopapular eruptions: Commonly seen in leptospirosis.
  4. Tender hepatomegaly: Suggests liver involvement, typical in leptospirosis-related jaundice.
  5. Laboratory findings:
    • Thrombocytopenia: Common in leptospirosis.
    • Raised bilirubin with moderately elevated AST/ALT: Indicates hepatocellular damage, typical in leptospirosis (bilirubin elevation is often disproportionate to liver enzyme levels).
    • Hematuria: Suggests renal involvement, often seen in leptospirosis.

Other options:
 

  1. Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever:

    • Typically presents with fever, thrombocytopenia, and plasma leakage. However, jaundice and calf tenderness are not common, and conjunctival suffusion is not a feature.

  2. Fulminant Hepatitis due to HAV:

    • While jaundice and fever are consistent, fulminant hepatitis due to HAV is characterized by severe liver failure (e.g., coagulopathy, encephalopathy), which is not seen here.

  3. Rickettsial Disease:

    • Rickettsial diseases may cause fever, rash, and thrombocytopenia, but jaundice and conjunctival suffusion are unusual.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1419, 1420.

questions.text: A patient presented with muscle weakness and polyuria. ECG showed prolonged QT interval, inverted T wave and U wave. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical and ECG findings, the diagnosis is most likely Hypokalemia. 

Option 2- Hyperkalemia ECG changes include tall T waves, prolonged PR interval and small p waves. In severe cases, wide QRS complexes and sine wave pattern is seen. 






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 168, 181, 296, 346.

questions.text: An elderly patient presented with tremors, rigidity and bradykinesia. Such a patient can be treated by giving:
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of Parkinson's disease. Among the given options, selegiline is used in the treatment of Parkinson disease. 
 
  • Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitor. It works by inhibiting the breakdown of dopamine in the brain, thus helping to alleviate symptoms of Parkinson's disease, particularly tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

Other options:
 

  • Haloperidol: This is an antipsychotic medication, but it can worsen the symptoms of Parkinson's disease by blocking dopamine receptors in the brain. It is not used to treat Parkinson’s and may actually induce drug-induced parkinsonism.

  • Clozapine: This is an atypical antipsychotic that has a lower risk of extrapyramidal side effects (such as parkinsonism) compared to other antipsychotics. However, it is primarily used for schizophrenia and not for treating Parkinson’s disease.

  • Donepezil: This is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used for Alzheimer's disease. It increases acetylcholine levels but does not directly address the dopamine deficiency in Parkinson’s disease and would not be an appropriate treatment for this condition.

Thus, Selegiline is the correct choice for treating Parkinsonian symptoms in this case.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 458, 459, 467, 468.

questions.text: A young female presented with severe throbbing headache on the left side. Before the onset of headache, she had nausea, vomiting, phonophobia and photophobia. Drug which can offer her immediate relief?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of classical migraine. Among the given options, Sumatriptan will be the drug of choice to terminate an acute attack.

It acts as an agonist at 5HTIB and 5HT1D receptors. 
 
  • Sumatriptan is a serotonin (5-HT) receptor agonist and is commonly used to abort or relieve acute migraine attacks. It works by constricting blood vessels and inhibiting the release of substances that contribute to the migraine pain. It provides rapid relief and is effective for the symptoms described (headache, nausea, photophobia, etc.).

Other options:
 

  • Propranolol: This is a beta-blocker and is commonly used as a prophylactic treatment for migraines, not for acute relief. It helps prevent future migraine attacks but does not provide immediate relief during an active episode.

  • Topiramate: This is an anticonvulsant medication that is used prophylactically to reduce the frequency of migraines. It is not effective for providing immediate relief during an acute migraine attack.

  • Cyproheptadine: This is an antihistamine with anti-serotonergic properties. While it has some off-label use for migraine prevention in certain cases, it is not a first-line treatment for acute relief of migraines.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3357, 3359, 3361, 3363.

questions.text: A 40 years old female  presented with arthralgia, oral ulcers, oliguria and hematuria. Urinary examination showed the presence of RBC casts. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is diagnostic of lupus nephritis. 
 

  • Lupus nephritis is a kidney manifestation of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease. It can present with a variety of symptoms, including arthralgia (joint pain), oral ulcers, and renal involvement, which can manifest as oliguria (decreased urine output), hematuria (blood in the urine), and RBC casts (which are indicative of glomerular damage). Other common findings in lupus nephritis can include proteinuria and hypertension.

  • Arthralgia and oral ulcers are classic systemic manifestations of SLE and commonly accompany renal involvement in lupus nephritis.


Other options:

  • Membranous glomerulonephritis: (Option 1) This primarily presents with nephrotic syndrome (proteinuria, edema, hypoalbuminemia) and does not typically present with systemic symptoms like oral ulcers or arthritis. It is less likely to cause RBC casts unless there is an additional complication like infection or another form of glomerulonephritis.

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis: (Option 2) This condition typically occurs after a throat or skin infection with group A streptococcus and is characterized by hematuria, proteinuria, edema, and hypertension. It usually presents in children and has a different clinical course than lupus nephritis. It does not explain the arthralgia or oral ulcers seen in this case.

  • Minimal change disease: (Option 3) This usually presents as nephrotic syndrome (proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema), and while it is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, it does not typically cause hematuria or RBC casts. It also does not explain the systemic symptoms such as oral ulcers or arthralgia.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2296, 2299, 2337-2339, 2736-2742.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and dry cough of 2 weeks duration. He is also having pain in left eye and bilateral facial weakness. His X-ray showed bilateral lymphadenopathy. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette goes in favor of sarcoidosis.

There are 2 syndromes associated with the condition
 
  1. Lofgren's syndrome- erythema nodosum+hilar lymphadenopathy.
  2. Mikulicz syndrome- Bilateral parotid involvement, submandibular and sublingual gland. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 461, 841, 844, 846, 852, 853, 1362, 2829-2832.

questions.text: A lady was some medications for some time. Now she is complaining of bleeding tendencies. Which vitamin deficiency is more likely in such a case?
questions.solution:
The most likely vitamin which is deficient in the given clinical scenario is vitamin K manifesting as bleeding tendencies. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 911, 912, 915.

questions.text: The two co-enzymes of riboflavin are FMN and FAD. Which of the following is used for evaluation of riboflavin activity?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, glutathione reductase is used for evaluation of riboflavin activity. 

Option 1- Transketolase is used for evaluation of vitamin B1-thiamine's activity. 


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 162, 163, 288, 290.

questions.text: A young male presented to the OPD with complaints of drooping of the left angle of mouth, inability to blow properly and weakness of the facial muscles on the left side. Which of the following cranial nerve/CN might be paralyzed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Bell's palsy which commonly involves the seventh cranial nerve-facial nerve. 
 

The facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII) controls the muscles of facial expression, including the muscles responsible for:

  • Raising the eyebrows
  • Closing the eyes tightly
  • Moving the mouth (such as smiling, frowning, and blowing)

The symptoms of drooping of the angle of the mouth, inability to blow properly, and weakness of the facial muscles are indicative of a facial nerve palsy, which can result from conditions such as Bell’s palsy, trauma, or stroke.


Other options:

  • 4th CN (Trochlear Nerve): This nerve controls the superior oblique muscle, which helps in eye movement. It does not affect facial muscles.
  • 5th CN (Trigeminal Nerve): This nerve provides sensation to the face and controls the muscles of mastication (chewing). While it can cause weakness in chewing muscles if affected, it does not cause the facial muscle weakness described in this case.
  • 6th CN (Abducent Nerve): This nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle, responsible for moving the eye laterally. It does not affect the facial muscles.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 229, 3439-3441.

questions.text: A 28 years old male patient presented with the complaints of fever, jaundice, upper abdominal pain and fatigue since last 2 months. His HBV infection markers were HBsAg positive and IgM anti-HBc antibody positive. What is true?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HbC goes in favor of acute HBV infection. 

Hepatitis B serological markers:




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 643, 2652-2564.

questions.text: A 45 year old lady presented with the complaints of amenorrhoea and galactorrhoea. Her urinary pregnancy test was positive. MRI of brain revealed a large pituitary mass. She was advised surgery but she refused. Which drug is best for managing such a case ?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of prolactinoma and the drug of choice for prolactinoma in a pregnant female is bromocriptine. 
 
  • Prolactinomas are the most common type of pituitary tumor and cause elevated prolactin levels, leading to symptoms like amenorrhoea (absence of menstruation), galactorrhoea (milky discharge from the breasts), and infertility.
  • Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist that works by stimulating dopamine receptors in the pituitary gland. This inhibits the secretion of prolactin and can reduce the size of the prolactinoma, helping normalize prolactin levels and relieve symptoms like galactorrhoea and amenorrhoea.

Other options:
 

  1. Leuprolide: This is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist. It is used to manage conditions like endometriosis and prostate cancer, but it is not effective for treating prolactinoma.

  2. Octreotide: This is a somatostatin analog, used primarily for acromegaly (growth hormone-secreting pituitary tumors) and certain types of carcinoid tumors. It is not effective in treating prolactinoma.

  3. Clozapine: This is an antipsychotic medication, and while it can cause increased prolactin levels, it is not used to treat prolactinomas. In fact, antipsychotics like clozapine can exacerbate symptoms of hyperprolactinemia.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2302, 2303, 2309-2311.

choices.text: Thorough debridement and closure of the wound

questions.text: A child was brought to the Surgical emergency after a stab wound. His clinical picture is shown below. What is the best way to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
In this patient of stab injury, there is evisceration of omentum through the wound as shown in the above image. Therefore the next course of action is to perform an emergency laparotomy. 


The indications of performing emergency laparotomy are as follows:
 
  1. Hemodynamic instability with FAST positivity. 
  2. Peritonitis
  3. Evisceration even if patient is hemodynamically stable.
  4. Gunshot injuries 


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 412-414.

questions.text: Study the label and identify the type of IV fluid:
questions.solution:
The fluid shown in the given image is ringer lactate or Hartmann's solution.

It is used in the following conditions:
 
  1. Correction of hypovolemia
  2. Metabolic acidosis
  3. Correction of hypokalemia
  4. Postoperative period, DKA, burns 





Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 281.

questions.text: A young male, who is a chronic alcoholic, presented to the Surgery OPD with complaints of whitish patches in the oral cavity. The clinical image is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis based on clinical scenario and the given image is leucoplakia. 
 
  • It is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity showing white patches or plaques which cannot be rubbed off. 
 
  • Speckled leucoplakia and proliferative verrucous leucoplakia are two important variants which carry higher risk of malignant transformation. 



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 761-763, 767.

questions.text: An old male presented to the Surgery OPD with the complaints of pain in the scrotum, fever and cellulitis of scrotal skin. Clinical image is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario along with image findings of gangrenous scrotal wall goes in favour of Fournier's gangrene. 
  • It is a polymicrobial infection involving the subcutaneous tissue leading to obliterative arteritis and gangrene. 
  • Management is emergency surgical debridement. 
  • Testis are usually spared in Fournier's gangrene due to dual blood supply. 


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1553.

questions.text: A young male had a road traffic accident and presented to the Emergency with the complaint of difficulty in breathing and chest pain. Gross examination of the chest showed bruises over the chest. He was tachypneic and tachycardic. His blood pressure was 90/60 mm Hg. Chest X-ray was done as shown below. What is the best/definitive treatment of such a patient?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario along with a hemodynamically unstable patient with BP less than 90/60 mm of Hg and CXR showing hyperlucent right hemothorax with absent broncho vascular markings and mediastinal shift. All the features are diagnostic of tension pneumothorax. 
 
  • Hence, the next best step would be to insert a wide bore needle in 5th intercostal space in mid-axillary line (Needle thoracocentesis) in order to relieve the tension component of pneumothorax. 
 
  • Definitive management: ICD placement and drainage and from 5th ICS at mid-axillary line.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 367.

Advanced Trauma Life Support- Student Course Manual, 10th edition, Page no 17, 66.

questions.text: A 5 years old child presented with history of recurrent urinary tract infections. A mass was palpable in the loin as well. Micturating cystourethrogram was done, which is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of recurrent urinary tract obstruction with the micturating cystourethrogram showing reflux of contrast into ureters which are dilated along with blunting of fornices and loss of renal papillary impression is diagnostic of Vesicoureteric reflux. 
  • It is more common in females as compared to males. 
  • Micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) is the investigation of choice for VUR.
  • It can also be graded based on the MCU appearance into 5 grades. 

Grading of VUR:





Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1404, 1436-1437, 1440.

questions.text: An 8 months old male child presented with sudden onset of abdominal pain with distension and vomiting. Per abdomen examination revealed a mass in right lumbar region. Attending surgeon ordered for Barium enema, which is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The given image shows classical claw sign/ coiled spring sign on barium enema. 
  • It is seen in resolving intussusception.
