questions.text: An elderly person, who is bed ridden for many years, was having a bedsore as shown in the figure. What is the grade of this bedsore?
questions.solution:
The given image is of Grade 4 pressure sore characterized by extensive tissue destruction extending up to the muscle layer. 

Grades of pressure sore:
 
  1. Stage 1- Erythema with no blanching or breach in the epidermis.
  2. Stage 2- Partial thickness skin loss with epidermal and dermal involvement.
  3. Stage 3- Full thickness skin loss with intact fascia but involvement of subcutaneous tissue. 
  4. Stage 4- Full thickness skin loss with involvement of muscle, bone, tendon or joint. 


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 29, 30.

questions.text: Amongst the following which is the most common site of intra-abdominal abscess:
questions.solution:
• Area marked as (1) represents the right sub-hepatic space which is the most common site of an intra-abdominal abscess. 
  • CT with intravenous contrast is the imaging method of choice for intra abdominal abscess. 
 
  • The right subhepatic space is a deep cavity located in Rutherford Morison's pouch.
  • It lies beneath the liver and above the transverse colon and hepatic flexure.

The boundaries of the right subhepatic space include:
  • the right lobe of the liver and diaphragm on the right side,
  • the foramen of Winslow on the left, the duodenum below,
  • the liver and gall bladder in the front, and
  • the right kidney and diaphragm at the back.

Abscesses in this area typically result from conditions like appendicitis, cholecystitis, perforated duodenal ulcers, or complications from upper abdominal surgeries. Intraperitoneal abscesses can also form due to intraperitoneal infections in specific abdominal sites (intra-abdominal abscess) or the pelvis (pelvic abscess). These abscesses may develop in subphrenic spaces or subhepatic spaces, on either the right or left side.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1055-1057.

questions.text: A patient presented to the Surgery OPD with the complaints of a swelling in the supraclavicular region on the right side. The swelling was smooth, compressible and pulsatile. Clinical image is given below. Next step in evaluating such a case:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of a tender pulsatile mass at the base of the neck makes it more likely to be a vascular anomaly, arteriovenous fistula or a venous aneurysm, both of which can present with pulsatile swelling.
 
  • Therefore, ultrasound doppler should be the next step in this patient. 
  • USG Doppler study is a non-invasive method to assess the nature of the swelling, particularly if it's related to blood vessels (e.g., an aneurysm, arteriovenous fistula, or venous malformation).
  • It can help evaluate blood flow, identify any vascular anomalies, and provide insight into whether the swelling is due to arterial or venous causes.
  • This diagnostic tool is typically used to confirm the diagnosis before proceeding with further interventions or management.

Other options:
 
  1. CT angiography + intervention: While this can be useful for vascular lesions, it would typically be performed after initial assessment with ultrasound or Doppler study to further define the lesion and its vascular characteristics. It is not usually the first step.
  2. Needle biopsy: A biopsy is not typically indicated for pulsatile, vascular swellings, as it may be difficult to interpret and unnecessary without understanding the vascular nature of the swelling first.
  3. Excision: Surgical excision is a therapeutic approach, not a diagnostic one. This should only be considered after determining the nature of the swelling via non-invasive imaging.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1925.

questions.text: A male patient came to the Surgery OPD with the complaints of claudication in buttocks, thigh and calves on both the sides. Distal arterial pulses were absent. He is having impotence also. Clinical image is shown below. Most likely level of obstruction:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of claudication in buttocks, thigh and calves with impotence along with the image showing gangrenous toe is suggestive of Leriche's syndrome. It is characterized by occlusion at the aortoiliac bifurcation. 
 

Leriche's syndrome is a condition caused by the obstruction of the aorta at its bifurcation into the iliac arteries, leading to reduced blood flow to the lower extremities and pelvis. It is typically caused by atherosclerosis.

Clinical features:

  • Triad of symptoms:
    1. Claudication (leg pain on exertion)
    2. Impotence (erectile dysfunction)
    3. Lower limb atrophy (muscle wasting due to poor circulation)
  • Other signs: Decreased femoral pulses, cold or pale legs, and possibly a bruit.
Diagnosis:
  • Doppler ultrasound, CT angiography, or MRA can confirm the diagnosis.

Treatment:
  • Conservative: Lifestyle changes, medications.
  • Interventional: Angioplasty, stenting, or surgical bypass in severe cases.

Leriche's syndrome typically results from atherosclerosis, and early intervention can improve outcomes.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 943-948.

questions.text: A 40 years old patient with thyroid carcinoma underwent thyroidectomy but on 4th post-operative day, he developed perioral tingling and carpo-pedal spasm. How to investigate this patient?
questions.solution:
• Hypoparathyroidism is a common complication following thyroid surgery. Usually, its a temporary phenomenon and lasts for 4-6 weeks. 
  • It can be diagnosed when there is decreased serum calcium and PTH levels.
  • Hypocalcemia is a common complication following thyroidectomy, often due to damage or removal of the parathyroid glands, which are responsible for regulating calcium levels in the body.
  • Estimation of calcium levels will help identify hypocalcemia, which can present with symptoms like tingling, muscle spasms, and seizures.
  • Parathormone (PTH) levels are crucial in differentiating whether the hypocalcemia is due to primary hypoparathyroidism (low PTH levels) or due to functional hypoparathyroidism (normal or high PTH levels in response to low calcium).
  • Phosphate levels may also be elevated in hypocalcemia as a result of impaired renal excretion due to low calcium.

Other options:
 
  1. Estimation of T3 and T4: While thyroid function tests are important in monitoring the thyroid status after thyroidectomy, they are less relevant to the acute issue of hypocalcemia and the symptoms of tingling and muscle spasms.
  2. Radioisotope iodine scan: This is used for detecting thyroid tissue or metastasis after thyroidectomy in thyroid cancer patients, but it is not relevant to the current symptoms of hypocalcemia.
  3. Thyroglobulin estimation: This is a tumor marker used to assess for recurrence of thyroid cancer after thyroidectomy, but it does not help in evaluating the cause of hypocalcemia.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 915.

questions.text: A young adult male presented to the Surgery OPD with the complaints of recurrent perianal openings over the buttock region. There is history of seropurulent discharge through those openings. Clinical picture of the patient is given below. Most likely diagnosis :
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of recurrent pain and discharge through perianal openings goes in favor of fistula-in-ano. 
 
  • Goodsall's rule is used to determine the location of the internal opening of the fistula. Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening with a short radial tract.
  • Fistulas with external opening located posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.
  • Exception- Fistulas with anterior external opening grater than 3 cm from the anal margin track to posterior midline. 


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1363-1367.

Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1408-1410.

questions.text: Study the image given below and make a clinical diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The above image is suggestive of ectopia vesicae or bladder exostrophy.

It occurs due to improper formation of lower anterior abdominal wall leaving the bladder open and exposed. 

Clinical features:
 
  • Appearance: The bladder is exposed outside the body, often appearing as a red, raw, and moist tissue mass. The bladder is open and not covered by skin.
 
  • Associated defects: Bladder exstrophy is often associated with other congenital anomalies, such as:
    • Epispadias (a malformation of the urethra, where the urethral opening is located on the upper side of the penis in males or on the clitoris in females).
    • Pubic symphysis separation (the bone structures of the pelvis may not be fully joined).
    • Cloacal exstrophy (a more severe variant involving defects in the bladder, intestines, and genitalia)


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1424, 1425.

questions.text: Study the intra-oral X-ray and make a diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• Presence of radio-opaque substance in the region of floor of mouth, likely in the region of Wharton's duct goes in favor of sialolithiasis.
 
  • Clinically, it presents with acute painful swelling in the submandibular region which is aggravated with food intake and resolution of symptoms 1-2 hours after the meal is completed.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 780, 781, 787.

questions.text: Following stripping surgery for varicose veins, patient started complaining of numbness along the medial aspect of the thigh. This is because injury to:
questions.solution:
• The saphenous nerve runs in close proximity to the great saphenous vein and innervates the medial aspect of thigh, leg upto the ball of great toe. 
 
  • Hence, it is prone for injury during surgery for varicose veins and can result in loss of sensations along its distribution. 

Other options:
 

  • Sural nerve: The sural nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral aspect of the foot and the lower part of the calf. It does not typically affect the medial thigh.

  • Deep peroneal nerve: This nerve innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the leg and provides sensation between the first and second toes. It does not affect the medial thigh.

  • Superficial peroneal nerve: This nerve provides sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot and the lateral aspect of the lower leg. It would not affect the medial thigh either.

Thus, the saphenous nerve is the most likely nerve injured following varicose vein stripping surgery, leading to numbness along the medial thigh.




Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 1399, 1415, 1416.

questions.text: A 40 years old female presented to the Surgery OPD with the complaint of lump in the breast. Clinical image of the breast is shown below. Such an appearance is because of :
questions.solution:
• The image shown above is of peau d'orange appearance.
  • It occurs due to infiltration of subdermal lymphatics by cancer cells.
  • Peau d'orange makes it a T4b disease (Skin involvement).

Other options:
 
  • Option 1- Involvement of Cooper's ligament results in dimpling and puckering. 
  • Option 3- Involvement of lactiferous ducts causes nipple retraction
  • Option 4- Involvement of chest wall makes it a T4a disease.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 860.

questions.text: A young male presented with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. He was sweating and have tachycardia. Per-abdominal examination revealed a tender and rigid abdomen. Attending surgeon ordered a plain X-ray abdomen in erect posture, which is shown below. What is the best way to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
• The given X-ray is a erect chest radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm.
  • It is indicative of hollow viscus perforation. 
  • The next best step in management among the given options is Resuscitation (with intravenous fluids) followed by emergency laparotomy. 


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1048, 1050-1052.

questions.text: Study the delayed intravenous urogram shown below and make a clinical diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• Delayed intravenous pyelogram of the patient shows left hydronephrosis with absence of contrast opacification of ispilateral ureter. This is most likely to be pelvi-ureteric junction obstruction on left side. 
 
  • Option 3- Putty kidney is characterized by dense renal parenchymal ( not pelvi-calyceal system ) calcifications visualized on a plain X-Ray KUB ( and not IVP )


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1402, 1405-1406, 1410-1412.

questions.text: A young male had a road traffic accident and presented to the Emergency department with inability to pass urine. Vitals were stable. On examination, there was blood at the tip of urethral meatus. A retrograde urethrogram was done as shown below. Most likely site of urethral rupture:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of a patient with road traffic accident, inability to pass urine with blood at the tip pf meatus, the retrograde urethrogram shows significant contrast extravasation in the region of membranous urethra. 
 
  • The investigation of choice in a patient with suspected urethral trauma is to perform a retrograde urethrography.
  • Loss of smooth contour of the urethra with extravasation of dye is diagnostic of urethral rupture. 



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1479-1481.

questions.text: A 50 years old female presented to the Surgery OPD with the complaints of single, smooth sweeling over the angle of mouth on the left side. It was firm and painless. Clinical image is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical image demonstrates the classical curtain sign, which is elevation of overlying ear lobule, characteristic of a parotid tumor. 

Options:
 

  • Osteoma of the angle of mandible: An osteoma is a benign bone tumor, but it typically presents as a hard, bony mass rather than a smooth, soft swelling. Osteomas are uncommon in this area, and they usually cause local discomfort or asymmetry rather than being completely painless.

  • Parotid tumor: The parotid gland is located near the angle of the mandible. Tumors of the parotid gland, such as pleomorphic adenomas, commonly present as a smooth, firm, and painless swelling in this location. The absence of pain is characteristic of benign parotid tumors.

  • Bezold's abscess: This is a deep neck abscess usually related to a bacterial infection that affects the muscles of the neck, particularly in the region of the mandible. It is typically associated with fever, pain, and other signs of infection, which are not mentioned in this case.

  • Cervical lymphadenopathy: Lymph nodes can swell due to various causes, but the swelling in this case is described as "smooth" and located specifically at the angle of the mouth, which is more typical of a parotid mass. Lymph nodes, if enlarged, would likely be more mobile and tender, and would not usually present as a firm, smooth mass at this location unless it was secondary to an infection or malignancy.

Therefore, parotid tumor is the most likely diagnosis based on the presentation of a smooth, firm, and painless swelling at the angle of the mouth. Further investigations like ultrasound or fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) can help confirm this diagnosis.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 839, 840.

questions.text: A road traffic accident patient with abdominal trauma was planned for emergency laparotomy. He was subjected to some investigation, as shown below. Identify the investigation:
questions.solution:
In a case of road traffic accident with significant abdominal trauma, intraoperative monitoring of coagulation is done by thromboelastography which is shown in the above image. 
 

Thromboelastography (TEG) is a test that evaluates the entire blood coagulation process, from clot formation to its breakdown. It measures the viscoelastic properties of blood, providing real-time information about clotting efficiency, strength, and stability.

Parameters:

  1. R-time: Time to initial clot formation.
  2. K-time: Time for clot to reach a defined firmness.
  3. Alpha angle: Speed of clot formation.
  4. Maximum Amplitude (MA): Strength of the clot.
  5. LY30: Percentage of clot breakdown after 30 minutes (fibrinolysis).
  6. Coagulation Index (CI): Overall coagulation status.

Uses:
 
  • Monitoring coagulation during surgery (e.g., cardiac or trauma surgeries).
  • Assessing bleeding disorders (e.g., liver disease, DIC).
  • Guiding blood product administration (e.g., platelets, plasma).
  • Evaluating thrombotic risk in high-risk patients.

Advantages:
 
  • Provides real-time, dynamic assessment of coagulation.
  • More comprehensive than standard tests like PT, aPTT, or INR.

Limitations:
  • Requires specialized equipment and trained staff.
  • Can be affected by factors like temperature and certain medications. 



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1161.

questions.text: A young patient presented with jaundice. Laboratory test revealed a bilirubin of 21 mg/dl, conjugated bilirubin is 9.6 mg/dl and alkaline phosphatase is 450 IU/I. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of elevated levels of ALP with bilirubin- conjugated and unconjugated elevated are indicative of obstructive jaundice. 

Other options:
 
  • Option 1- Hemolytic anemia will result in isolated elevation of unconjugated bilirubin. 
  • Option 2 and 3- Hepatic cause of jaundice will result in elevated levels of AST and ALT out of proportion to ALP. Increase in bilirubin is also seen. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 315-319.

Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 135.

choices.text: Arrange blood and deliver placenta by Crede's method

questions.text: While performing the procedure shown in the figure below, the umbilical cord got torn. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows Brant-Andrews maneuver which is controlled cord traction for delivery of placenta.
  • The next step in management is manual removal of placenta to remove the source of hemorrhage.

The Brant-Andrews method of controlled cord traction is a technique used to assist in the delivery of the placenta during the third stage of labor, aimed at minimizing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) and ensuring the safe expulsion of the placenta.

Steps:

  1. Wait for placental separation: Signs like lengthening of the umbilical cord and uterine rise indicate the placenta is ready to be delivered.
  2. Apply controlled cord traction: Gently pull on the umbilical cord while simultaneously applying counter-pressure on the uterus to prevent inversion.
  3. Monitor uterine contraction: The uterus should contract to help expel the placenta.
  4. Ensure placental integrity: Avoid excessive traction to prevent cord rupture or uterine injury.

Benefits:
 
  • Reduces the risk of uterine inversion and bleeding.
  • Facilitates safe and timely placental expulsion.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 526, 527, 758, 759.

choices.text: Wait and watch for normal vaginal delivery

questions.text: A primigravida pregnant lady was in labor with a fetus in right occipital-posterior presentation. Uterine contractions are good. Next step in the management of such a patient:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of right occipito-posterior position with adequate uterine contractions can be managed by normal vaginal delivery. Therefore the correct answer to this question will be option 2. 
 

  • Occipital-posterior (OP) presentation means that the baby's head is positioned with the occiput (back of the head) facing the mother's back. This is a less favorable position for vaginal delivery, as it can lead to a longer labor, increased pain, and a higher likelihood of interventions. However, in most cases, good uterine contractions and a primigravida status (first pregnancy) allow the possibility of a normal vaginal delivery with supportive care and monitoring.

  • Spontaneous rotation: Many fetuses in OP position will rotate to the occipital-anterior (OA) position during labor, which is more favorable for vaginal delivery. Waiting and watching is appropriate in this case as the labor progresses.



Other options:

  1. Cesarean section: This is usually indicated for failure to progress, non-reassuring fetal heart rate, or other obstetric complications. In the absence of such issues, waiting for a vaginal delivery is preferred.

  2. Start oxytocin drip: Oxytocin is used to augment labor if contractions are inadequate. However, in this case, the contractions are already good, so there's no immediate need for augmentation.

  3. Forceps delivery: This is an instrumental delivery used when the fetus is in a difficult position or if there's failure to progress, but the OP presentation itself does not necessarily require forceps delivery unless there's fetal distress or prolonged labor.

Thus, waiting and monitoring the progress of labor is the best approach for this patient with a fetus in OP presentation. 



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 424-433.

questions.text: The area drawn in green colour represents:
questions.solution:
The green color area depicts mid-pelvis. It is bounded by the plane of greatest pelvic dimension above and mid-pelvis plane below. 
 

  • Location:

    • The mid-pelvis is the space between the pelvic inlet (upper border) and the pelvic outlet (lower border).
    • It is narrower than the pelvic inlet but wider than the pelvic outlet.
 

  • Significance in Labor:

    • The fetus must navigate through the mid-pelvis during the second stage of labor (descent). This involves the engagement, descent, and rotation of the fetal head.
    • In cases where the fetus is in occipital-posterior or other malpositions, the mid-pelvis may present challenges for the fetus to rotate and descend properly.







Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 101, 102, 104.

questions.text: On 7th day of a normal vaginal delivery, a lady was brought to the emergency department at midnight with the complaints of loss of appetite, depression, difficulty in sleeping and occasional crying. General examination and pelvic examination were normal. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Postpartum blues is the most likely diagnosis in a postpartum woman with above clinical features from day 7.
 
  • They develop 3-5 days after delivery and resolve spontaneously within 10-14 days. 
 
  • Management involves reassurance, education and support.  

POSTPARTUM MOOD DISORDERS





Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 512.

questions.text: A 25 years old lady complaints of right sided lower abdominal pain and mild bleeding per vaginum for one day after a period of amenorrhoea of 6 weeks. Her general condition is satisfactory and the vitals were stable. There is tenderness in the right iliac fossa. HCG level was 1400 IU/ml. Transvaginal ultrasound scan does not reveal any adnexal mass or any intrauterine pregnancy but the uterus was bulky and trilaminar endometrium was seen. There was no fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
• The two possibilities based on the above clinical stem is either an abortion or ectopic pregnancy. 
 
  • Therefore, the next best step is to repeat b-HCG after 48 hours. 
 
  • Ectopic pregnancy should be suspected based on clinical symptoms (abdominal pain, bleeding, and positive pregnancy test with no visible intrauterine pregnancy).
  • In this case, beta-HCG is positive but lower than expected for an intrauterine pregnancy (usually >1500 IU/ml to be visible on ultrasound).
  • The next step is to repeat the beta-HCG after 48 hours to check if the levels are doubling. In a normal intrauterine pregnancy, beta-HCG should rise appropriately (typically doubling every 48 hours). In an ectopic pregnancy, the beta-HCG may rise more slowly or plateau.
  • If the beta-HCG levels fail to double or remain stable, it strongly suggests an ectopic pregnancy, and further management, including surgical intervention or medical treatment (such as methotrexate), may be needed.

Other options:
 

  1. Perform a laparoscopic examination:

    • While laparoscopic examination is a definitive diagnostic tool for ectopic pregnancy, it is invasive. A repeated beta-HCG test would provide more information about the pregnancy’s progression before opting for surgical intervention. Laparoscopy is typically reserved for cases where the diagnosis remains uncertain or if the patient is unstable.

  2. Repeat USG after a week:

    • Waiting a week without further investigation could delay the diagnosis and management of a potentially life-threatening ectopic pregnancy. The beta-HCG test is more useful for timely decision-making.

  3. Give progesterone:

    • Progesterone supplementation is not indicated in this case. If the patient had threatened abortion or luteal phase insufficiency, progesterone might be considered, but this presentation suggests a more serious condition, such as ectopic pregnancy, which needs further diagnostic workup.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 371-378.

questions.text: A primigravida with full term pregnancy and in labor presented with sign and symptoms, of dehydration. Her heart was 105 beats/minute, BP of 130/90 mm of Hg. Per abdominal examination showed a fundal height of 32 weeks, and the fetus was having right occipito transverse position. Fetal heart sounds were feeble and mild uterine contractions were felt. Per vaginal examination revealed a fully dilated cervix, head is at the level of ischial spine, caput was present and moulding was also present. Pelvis was found to be inadequate. What will be the most appropriate management of such a case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical feature is diagnostic of cephalo-pelvic disproportion. The management in this scenario would be option 2. 
 
  • Inadequate pelvis with fetal distress (feeble fetal heart sounds) and moulding of the fetal head suggest that labor is not progressing adequately. Moulding is a sign of obstructed labor, which can occur when the fetal head cannot pass through the birth canal due to cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD).
  • The right occipito-transverse position is a malposition, and while it can sometimes rotate during labor, the presence of moulding and caput suggests that the fetus is struggling to navigate the pelvic canal.
  • Fetal heart rate abnormalities and feeble fetal heart sounds are concerning for fetal distress, and this may worsen if labor continues without appropriate intervention.
  • Cesarean section is indicated when there is a failure of labor progress, mechanical obstruction (inadequate pelvis), or fetal distress, as continuing with vaginal delivery could compromise the safety of both the mother and fetus,

Other options:
 

  1. Injection oxytocin:

    • Oxytocin is used to augment or induce labor when contractions are inadequate. However, in this case, mild uterine contractions are present, and the problem appears to be mechanical (due to the inadequate pelvis and fetal distress), not one of insufficient contraction strength. Giving oxytocin could worsen the fetal distress or further obstruct the labor.

  2. Ventouse delivery:

    • Vacuum-assisted delivery (ventouse) is indicated in situations where the head is low enough in the birth canal (station 0 or +1) and there is fetal distress or a need for assistance in the second stage of labor. However, in this case, the fetal head is at the level of the ischial spine and there is inadequate pelvis, which makes a vacuum delivery potentially dangerous due to the risk of injury to both the mother and fetus.

  3. Forceps applications:

    • Forceps delivery is generally performed when the fetal head is well engaged and at or below the ischial spines. While forceps could be considered if labor is obstructed and the fetus is not in distress, in this case, the inadequate pelvis and fetal distress make forceps a less safe option. Furthermore, the head is still at the level of the ischial spine, and there is a concern about cephalopelvic disproportion.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 91, 97, 98, 424-427, 670.

choices.text: Incomplete invasion of extra-villous cytotrophoblast into uterine artery
Incomplete invasion of extra-villous cytotrophoblast into radial artery
Incomplete invasion of extra-villous cytotrophoblast into basal artery
Incomplete invasion of extra-villous cytotrophoblast into spiral artery

questions.text: A pregnant lady with 32 weeks pregnancy develops hypertension and edema. Urine examination shows presence of protein. Treating doctor suspected it to be a case of preeclampsia. Which of the following theory defines it:
questions.solution:
The pathophysiology of pre-eclampsia revolves around incomplete invasion of extra villous cytotrophoblast into spiral artery. 

  • During normal pregnancy, extra-villous cytotrophoblasts invade the spiral arteries (which are part of the maternal uterine blood supply to the placenta) to remodel them.
  • This remodeling process transforms the spiral arteries from high-resistance vessels to low-resistance vessels that allow sufficient blood flow to the placenta.
  • In preeclampsia, this process of invasion and remodeling is incomplete or defective. As a result, the spiral arteries remain narrower and high-resistance, leading to poor placental perfusion and ischemia.
  • The placental ischemia releases various factors into the maternal circulation, including soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase-1 (sFlt-1) and endoglin, which can impair the endothelial function, causing the hallmark features of preeclampsia: hypertension, proteinuria, and edema.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 257, 263, 265, 266.

questions.text: What will be the position of the uterus on 2nd postpartum day?
questions.solution:
On second day post delivery, the uterus lies two finger breadth below the umbilicus. 
 
  • After delivery, the uterus gradually involutes (shrinks and returns to its pre-pregnancy size).
  • On the first postpartum day, the uterus is usually at the level of the umbilicus.
 
  • By the second postpartum day, it typically descends slightly and can be felt about 2 finger breadths below the umbilicus.
  • The uterus continues to shrink over the next few days, and by the end of the first week postpartum, it is usually about half its size compared to before delivery and can be felt around the symphysis pubis.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 169,170.

Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 635.

questions.text: A lady with pre-eclampsia presented to the Emergency department with absent patellar reflexes and bilateral plantar reflexes. She was having a respiratory rate of 11 breaths/minute and decreased urinary output. On auscultation, lung fields were clear. Her random blood sugar value was 210 mg/dl. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is suggestive of magnesium sulphate toxicity. 
 
  • Its therapeutic levels are 4-7 mEq/L.
 
  • Signs of Magnesium toxicity include- loss of deep tendon reflexes, decreased RR < 12/min, decreased urine output < 30 ml/hour and visual changes, drowsiness. 



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 268, 273.

questions.text: A lady with 12 weeks of pregnancy presented for antenatal check-up. What would be your advice regarding calorie requirements?
questions.solution:
Additional 300 kcal is recommended in second trimester. 
 
  • For a pregnant woman, an additional 300 kcal per day is generally recommended in the second trimester.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics, energy needs remain similar to non-pregnant women in the first trimester but increase by 340 kcal in the second trimester and by 452 kcal in the third trimester.
  • The Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) advises an extra 300 kcal during both the second and third trimesters. Therefore, option 1 is more accurate in this context.

Pregnancy demands additional nutrients to support fetal growth and development. The National Institute of Nutrition suggests the following increases for pregnant women:

  • Protein: An extra 23 g/day compared to non-pregnant women
  • Fat: 30 g/day
  • Calcium: 1200 mg/day
  • Iron: 35 mg/day

During lactation, the ICMR recommends increasing caloric intake by 550 kcal/day for the first six months and by 400 kcal/day from 7–12 months of lactation.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 167.
National Institute of Nutrition (NIN) guidelines, URL: https://www.nin.res.in/rdabook/brief_note.pdf

choices.text: Perform an elective cesarean section at 39 weeks of pregnancy
Perform an external cephalic version at 36 weeks of pregnancy
Induction of labor, if not delivered till 40 weeks

questions.text: A 26 years old primipara with normal BMI attended the antenatal clinic. She is having amenorrhoea of 35 weeks and a single live fetus in breech presentation. USG demonstrated complete breech presentation and adequate liquor volume. There was no other abnormality on USG scan. Her pregnancy is otherwise uncomplicated. What should be done next:
questions.solution:
• The next step is to perform an external cephalic version at 36 weeks of pregnancy to convert into cephalic presentation for normal vaginal delivery.
  • Primigravida with breech is relative contraindication to C-Section
 
  • External Cephalic Version (ECV) is a procedure in which the fetus is manually turned from the breech position to a head-down (vertex) position. It is typically done between 36 to 37 weeks of pregnancy.
  • Breech presentation at term (around 37 weeks onwards) increases the risk of complications during labor, including cord prolapse, fetal distress, and birth trauma. Therefore, efforts are often made to turn the baby to a cephalic (head-down) position before labor begins.
  • ECV has a success rate of around 50-60% and is generally safe for uncomplicated breech pregnancies in women who have a normal BMI, and no contraindications to the procedure.
  • If the ECV is successful, the patient can proceed with vaginal delivery. If it is unsuccessful, the delivery will likely proceed by cesarean section.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 539, 542, 543, 549.

questions.text: A 24 years old primigravida had postpartum hemorrhage, hypotension, shock and disseminated intravascular coagulation following normal vaginal delivery of a fully-term healthy infant. Uterus is well contracted and hard. Fetus is normal. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of DIC post delivery goes in favor of amniotic fluid embolism. 




Other options:
 

  • Ruptured uterus:

    • A ruptured uterus would typically present with severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and loss of fetal heart tones during labor. The uterus is usually soft and tender to palpation, and a rupture often leads to fetal distress or fetal death. Since the fetus is described as healthy and the uterus is well contracted, uterine rupture is less likely.

  • Vaginal laceration:

    • Vaginal lacerations can cause postpartum hemorrhage but usually result in localized bleeding from the vaginal or perineal area. They are less likely to cause the systemic shock, DIC, and severe hypotension seen in this case. Additionally, vaginal lacerations would not explain the well-contracted uterus.

  • Uterine atony:

    • Uterine atony is one of the most common causes of postpartum hemorrhage, but it typically presents with a soft, boggy uterus that does not contract properly. Since the uterus is described as well-contracted and hard in this case, uterine atony is unlikely.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 756, 785, 786.

questions.text: A known case of cervical incompetence with previous abortion presented at 12 weeks of pregnancy. Doctor planned her for cerclage operation. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for cervical cerclage operation?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, rupture of membranes is an absolute contraindication to perform cervical cerclage. 

Contraindications for cervical cerclage are-
  1. Ruptured membranes
  2. Intrauterine infection
  3. Uterine contractions
  4. Vaginal bleeding 
  5. Cervix > 4 cm dilated


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 197-201, 367.

questions.text: A 14 weeks pregnant lady was subjected to Color Doppler studies of Uterine artery. By doing so, which of the following can be diagnosed?
questions.solution:
• A uterine artery doppler will detect early onset pre-eclampsia. 
  • It will show presence of a diastolic notch and resistance to flow in uterine artery. 
 
  • Color Doppler of the uterine artery is primarily used to assess placental perfusion by examining the blood flow through the uterine arteries. This can give valuable information regarding maternal vascular health and potential pregnancy complications.
  • Early onset pre-eclampsia (which typically develops before 34 weeks of gestation) is associated with abnormal uterine artery Doppler findings, such as:
    • Increased resistance to blood flow (higher pulsatility index).
    • Notching of the uterine artery waveform.
  • These abnormal Doppler findings reflect impaired trophoblastic invasion and poor placental perfusion, which can contribute to the development of early-onset pre-eclampsia.

Other options:
 

  1. Late onset pre-eclampsia:

    • Late onset pre-eclampsia (occurring after 34 weeks) is less likely to be predicted by early Doppler studies, as it is often associated with less severe placental dysfunction compared to early onset. Doppler abnormalities tend to be more predictive for early onset pre-eclampsia, where placental pathology plays a more significant role.

  2. Growth retardation (Fetal growth restriction):

    • Fetal growth restriction (FGR) can be associated with abnormal Doppler findings in the uterine artery, but it is typically diagnosed later in pregnancy (often after 20 weeks or later) when fetal growth begins to deviate from expected norms. While early signs may be present, Doppler studies at 14 weeks are more specific to assessing pre-eclampsia risk rather than diagnosing growth retardation directly.

  3. Placenta accreta:

    • Placenta accreta involves abnormal attachment of the placenta to the uterine wall, which is more likely to be diagnosed through ultrasound imaging with color Doppler of the placenta in later stages of pregnancy (typically after 20 weeks). Doppler studies of the uterine artery at 14 weeks are not helpful in diagnosing placenta accreta.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 214, 340, 712, 713, 777, 778.

questions.text: A lady with 22 weeks of pregnancy presented with painless severe vaginal bleeding. Most likely site of implantation is:
questions.solution:
The most likely site of implantation in this case is the cervix.

Painless severe vaginal bleeding in the second trimester is highly suggestive of placenta previa. In placenta previa, the placenta implants abnormally over the cervix, leading to bleeding as the lower uterine segment stretches. The bleeding is typically painless because it originates from the placenta unlike placental abruption, which causes painful bleeding due to uterine detachment.

Clinical Features of Placenta Previa:

  1. Painless Vaginal Bleeding: The hallmark symptom is bright red, painless vaginal bleeding, typically occurring in the second or third trimester (after 20 weeks of pregnancy).

  2. Abnormal Fetal Position: Due to the placenta covering the cervical os, the fetus may be in a breech or transverse lie.

  3. Uterine Contractions: Mild uterine contractions may accompany bleeding, but they are usually not as severe as in other conditions like abruptio placentae.

  4. Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH): -There is a high risk of massive postpartum hemorrhage due to the placenta obstructing the cervical os during delivery. 

Other options
- The fallopian tube is the most common site for ectopic pregnancy, which usually presents with first-trimester pain and rupture rather than painless bleeding at 22 weeks.
- The ovary and abdomen are rare sites of ectopic pregnancy, which do not typically progress to the second trimester.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 755-757.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for first-trimester termination of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Misoprostol and mifepristone are used for medical termination of pregnancy in first 9 weeks of gestation. 
 
  • Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. 
  • Misoprostol 800 mcg is administered on day 3 by vaginal, sublingual or buccal route. 



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 203, 204.

questions.text: A 25 years old lady with a 24 months baby has heavy irregular bleeding during menstruation. The baby is on breast feed. Which of the following contraceptive agent is advised to such a patient?
questions.solution:
The contraceptive of choice in a lactating mother with heavy irregular bleeding is MALA-N. 
 
  • MALA N is a combined oral contraceptive (COC) that contains 20-30 mcg of ethinyl estradiol (EE2) and 0.15 mg of levonorgestrel. It works by inhibiting ovulation through the suppression of pituitary hormones, FSH and LH.
 
  • COCs have the lowest failure rates and are effective in managing conditions like polymenorrhea, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia. However, the risk of thromboembolism is highest during the first 6 weeks postpartum (puerperal period) with COCs, and they are known to suppress lactation.
 
  • In this case, since the child is 24 months old (and complementary feeding typically begins at 6 months, meaning the child is not fully dependent on breastmilk for nutrition) and the woman is well beyond the puerperal period, MALA N can be safely used.



Other options:

  • Option 1: Norethisterone enanthate depot is an intramuscular injection given every 2 months. Though it is suitable for lactating women, it has an increased risk of irregular menstrual cycle and low BMD. So, it is not preferred in this case.
 
  • Option 2: Copper T is not recommended for this patient, as it may worsen menorrhagia and lead to anemia.
 
  • Option 3: Progestasert is a hormone-releasing IUCD that prevents sperm entry by creating a thick mucus plug at the cervix. Its use is limited in cases of heavy, unexplained bleeding.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 682.

Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 16th edition, Page no 269-271, 273-277.

questions.text: Blood test reports of a 24 weeks pregnant lady revealed AST and ALT>70 IU/l, bilirubin >1.2 mg/dl and platelet counts 90,000/mm3. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings of elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin along with low platelet count indicates diagnosis of HELLP syndrome. 

Tennesse criteria is used to diagnose HELLP syndrome. It includes-
  1. Platelet count <1 lac/mm3
  2. AST>70 IU/L
  3. LDH>600 
  4. Hemolysis




Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 258, 259.

questions.text: Which one of the following option is a contraindication for the use of contraceptive shown in the image?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows Copper containing IUCD- Multiload 375.
  • Among the given options, undiagnosed vaginal bleeding is an absolute contraindication for its use. 





Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 615, 616, 630.

choices.text: Avoid intercourse for 1 month; Defer pregnancy for at least 6 months
Avoid intercourse for 3 months; Defer pregnancy for at least 1 year
Avoid intercourse for 6 months; Defer pregnancy for at least 2 years
Avoid intercourse for 1 year; Defer pregnancy for at least 6 years

questions.text: A young lady was operated for Vesicovaginal fistula. As a doctor, what advice will you give her at the time of discharge?
questions.solution:
A patient who has undergone vesicovaginal fistula repair, sexual intercourse should be avoided for at least 3 months whereas pregnancy should be avoiding for an year. 



Reference: William's Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no 580.

Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 16th edition, Page no 220-223.

questions.text: Study the hysterosalpingogram given below and make a diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given hysterosalpingogram is suggestive of septate uterus. 
 
  • It shows smooth fundal contour with widely diverging horns and an intercornual angle of less than 75 degrees. 
 
  • Bicornuate uterus, on the other hand, will show indented fundus with an intercornual angle of more than 75 degrees. 


Reference: William's Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no 34, 35, 43, 421, 422.

Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 71, 72.

questions.text: A known case of HIV is taking HAART. How to evaluate efficacy of treatment?
questions.solution:
The evaluation of efficacy of HAART in a case of HIV is done with the help of viral load. 
 

In a known case of HIV undergoing Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy (HAART), the efficacy of the treatment is primarily evaluated by measuring the viral load. This is the amount of HIV RNA present in the blood.

  • Viral load: The main indicator of treatment efficacy. If HAART is effective, the viral load should decrease significantly over time and ideally become undetectable (usually <20-50 copies/ml). A decrease in viral load indicates that the treatment is working to suppress the virus. Monitoring viral load helps assess how well the antiretroviral therapy is controlling the virus.

Other options:
 

  • ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay): This is primarily used for HIV screening and not for evaluating the efficacy of HAART. It detects HIV antibodies but doesn't provide direct information about viral replication or treatment success.

  • p24 antigen: This test detects a core protein of HIV and can be used in early HIV infection (before antibodies develop), but it's not routinely used to assess the efficacy of HAART in an established HIV infection.

  • Western blot: This is a confirmatory test for HIV infection after an initial positive screening test (e.g., ELISA). It's not used to assess the effectiveness of antiretroviral treatment. 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1560, 1595, 1596.

questions.text: A patient presented with pitting of nails, subungual hyperkeratosis and oil drop changes. Clinical image is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Irregular pitting of nails, subungal hyperkeratosis and oil drop changes are seen in psoriasis. 




Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, Volume- II, 9th edition, Page no 35.1, 35.8, 35.9, 35.10.

questions.text: A known case of borderline tuberculoid leprosy was undergoing treatment. Which of the following nerve is commonly affected in such a case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is in favor of leprosy. The most common cranial nerve involved in leprosy is 7th cranial nerve. 
 
  • Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which primarily affects the skin, peripheral nerves, and mucous membranes.
  • The posterior tibial nerve is most commonly involved, followed by the ulnar, median, and lateral popliteal nerves.
  • The facial nerve is the most frequently affected cranial nerve.
  • Leprosy has a prolonged incubation period, typically ranging from 2 to 12 years. It often presents as a numb area on the skin or a visible skin lesion, which may appear as a hypopigmented or erythematous macule.
  • Lesions typically occur on the face, extensor surfaces of the limbs, trunk, and buttocks. These lesions are associated with impaired nerve function and poor hair growth. Patients may also develop burns or ulcers on the affected anesthetic limb.


Leprosy is classified using two main systems:

  • Ridley-Jopling classification:
    • Tuberculoid (TT)
    • Borderline tuberculoid (BT)
    • Borderline (BB)
    • Borderline lepromatous (BL)
    • Lepromatous (LL)
 
  • WHO classification:
    • Paucibacillary
    • Multibacillary



Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, Volume- II, 9th edition, Page no 28.1, 28.3, 28.13.

questions.text: A female presented to the Dermatology OPD with the complaints of hair loss for 3 weeks. She had a history of COVID-19 infection 3 months back. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and image is telogen effluvium. 
 
  • It is a non scarring type of alopecia with marked diffuse shedding of normal hair due to premature termination of anagen phase of hair cycle. 
  • It is usually seen 2-3 months after stressful events such as surgery, fever. It resolves spontaneously. 


Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, Volume- III, 9th edition, Page no 32.24, 32.39, 32.40.

questions.text: An obese lady presented to the Skin OPD with the complaints of dark patches over neck as shown in the figure. It is associated with:
questions.solution:
The given clinical image demonstrates hyperpigmented velvety lesions in the skin flexure at the back of neck, known as acanthosis nigricans. 

It is commonly associated with metabolic syndrome. 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 390, 2933, 2934, 2936, 2970, 2971, 3154-3156.

questions.text: Which nerve is tested to monitor neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows neuromuscular monitoring. 
 
  • The most commonly used nerve for monitoring is ulnar nerve.
  • It is tested by asking the patient to perform adduction of the thumb since adductor pollicis receives its nerve supply from ulnar nerve.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1356, 1357, 1361.

questions.text: Identify the equipment used commonly for COVID-19 patients:
questions.solution:
The given equipment is a non-rebreathable face mask (NRBM).
 
  • It is commonly used in COVID-19 patients who require supplemental oxygen.
  • It has a reservoir bad attached to it to provide additional volume. 
  • It can provide the highest FiO2 of 0.9-1 without intubation. 



Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology, 6th edition, Page no 1333-1334.

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown below:
questions.solution:
The given imaging modality is PET-CT scan. 

It is a hybrid/fusion imaging technique which combines PET and CT scan providing both metabolic/functional and anatomical details. 



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1642, 1643.

questions.text: A 30 years male smoker presented with pain in left foot and calf, which was of acute onset. His dorsalis pedis pulsations were feeble. Attending doctor advised for some investigation, which is shown below. Identify the radiological investigation:
questions.solution:
The given radiological investigation is that of an ultrasound doppler demonstrating the classical triphasic waveform of high resistance lower limb vessels. 
 
  • A triphasic waveform typically indicates normal peripheral arterial flow, but it can also sometimes be seen in certain pathological conditions like early-stage peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
  • The Doppler study provides real-time information about the arterial blood flow, and the triphasic waveform would be recorded during this test as a part of the assessment of the arterial pulse and the adequacy of blood supply to the foot and calf.

Other options:
 

  • Digital subtraction angiography (DSA): While DSA is used for detailed vascular imaging and could provide information about blockages or narrowing of arteries, it does not typically provide waveforms like those seen in Doppler studies.

  • MR angiography: Similar to DSA, MR angiography is used for detailed imaging of blood vessels but does not assess blood flow waveforms in real-time as ultrasound Doppler does.

  • Plethysmography: This test measures limb volume changes, which can indicate changes in blood flow but does not provide detailed waveform analysis like Doppler ultrasound.


     

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 945, 946.

questions.text: A young patient presented with high-grade fever, cough with purulent expectoration and difficulty in breathing. High Resolution CT of chest was done as shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The given image is an axial CT scan of thorax demonstrating the classical 'air-bronchogram sign' with surrounding lung parenchymal consolidation.
 
  • This radiological finding coupled with symptoms of high grade fever, cough with purulent expectoration and dyspnea goes in favor of community acquired pneumonia. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1011, 2200.

questions.text: A 15 years old girl is having irresistible desire to eat. She also takes appetite suppressants. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in the above clinical scenario is bulimia nervosa. 
 
  • It is an eating disorder characterized by binge-eating episodes followed by compensatory mechanisms in the form of self induced vomiting, diuretics or laxative abuse. The weight of the patient is near normal. 
 
  • This has to be distinguished from binge eating disorder wherein excessive binge eating episodes are not followed by compensatory mechanisms. This makes the patient overweight/obese. 



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 363, 509, 511, 512, 514.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the Emergency department by his relatives. He was having respiratory depression and relatives suspected him to have overdosed with Opioids. Which drug is best used in managing such a case?
questions.solution:
The answer to the above question is Naloxone. It is an opioid antagonist given intravenously to reverse the effects of opioid toxicity. 
 
  • Naloxone is an opioid antagonist and is the first-line treatment for opioid overdose, particularly in cases of respiratory depression. It works by binding to opioid receptors in the brain, reversing the effects of opioids, including respiratory depression, sedation, and hypotension. It can be administered intramuscularly or intravenously and can rapidly reverse the life-threatening effects of opioid overdose.

Other options:
 

  • Naltrexone: (Option 1)- Although naltrexone is also an opioid antagonist, it is administered orally. Hence it is not preferred in emergency management of opioid overdose. 

  • Flumazenil: (Option 3) This is a benzodiazepine antagonist, used to reverse the effects of benzodiazepine overdose, not opioids. It would not be effective in managing an opioid overdose.

  • Clonidine: (Option 4) This is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, used in the management of opioid withdrawal symptoms, but it is not effective for reversing respiratory depression caused by opioid overdose.




Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 383.

questions.text: A child had a fall on ground over his left shoulder. After this he presented to the Emergency department with pain and swelling over left shoulder and he was supporting his left elbow with right hand. X-ray of the child is shown below. Which of the bone is fractured?
questions.solution:
The most likely bone fractured in the given clinical scenario is clavicle- marked as (1). 
 
  • It occurs due to direct blow or fall on outstretched arm.
  • The middle 1/3rd of the shaft is the most common site of fracture.
  • The lateral fragment is pulled down by the weight of the arm whereas the medial half is pulled up by sternocleidomastoid muscle. 
 
  • Therefore, the patient will present with flexed elbow so as to keep the arm close to chest wall and prevent its movement. 



Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 675, 755-758, 770.

questions.text: A G2P1 lady in the second trimester of pregnancy went for antenatal check-up. USG showed fractures in multiple long bones in the fetus. Fetus is suffering from:
questions.solution:
Multiple long bone fractures is commonly seen in osteogenesis imperfecta. 

It is a connective tissue disorder due to abnormal type 1 collagen. 


Other options:
 
  • Option 1- Fetal hypothyroidism results in cretinism with features of deafness-mutism, squint and mental retardation.
 
  • Option 2- Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant skeletal dysplasia with disproportionately short limbs. It affects the bones which ossify by enchondral ossification. Note- IQ is normal in this condition. 
 
  • Option 4- Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder with features of long limbs and digits, tall height, risk of spontaneous pneumothorax, aortic dissection, superotemporal dislocation of lens. 



Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 123, 164, 165, 170, 178.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple swellings in the right hand. X-ray suggest the diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the woman is multiple enchondromas.
 
  • The X-ray shows intralesional calcifications with popcorn appearance. 
  • It is an epiphyseal tumor.
 
  • Multiple enchondromatosis is also known as Ollier disease.
  • Enchondromas with overlying soft tissue hemangiomas are known as Maffucci Syndrome. 


Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 175, 176.

questions.text: Identify the injury and the surgical procedure done as shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
In the given image, the bones above and below the knee joint are fixed using a spanning external fixator for periarticular fracture. 
 

  • Indications: Spanning fixators are often used in cases of:

    • Complex fractures: Especially in cases where internal fixation (such as plates or screws) might not be sufficient or possible.
    • Open fractures: In situations where there is significant soft tissue damage or contamination.
    • Joint fractures: When fractures involve a joint and there is concern about preserving joint function during healing.
    • Distraction osteogenesis: In certain cases, spanning fixators are used for bone lengthening procedures.



Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 330, 726, 727.

questions.text: What would be the best treatment plan for the injury in an adult, shown below in the X-ray?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows bimalleolar fracture of tibia and fibula with intra-articular extension in underlying ankle joint.

Any intra-articular fracture is a fracture of necessity and requires urgent operative fixation. 



Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 712, 746.

questions.text: What could be the most common set of complications, if the injury shown in the X-ray below is not treated properly?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows fracture of lateral condyle of humerus. 
 
  • Cubitus valgus is the most common complication of an untreated lateral condyle fracture of humerus.
 
  • Lateral condyle fracture of humerus has a tendency to go into non-union. 


Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 187, 386, 784-786.

questions.text: A child presented to the OPD with the complaints of pain in forearm and leg. X-ray showed diaphyseal sclerosis. Peripheral smear of the patient is shown below. Organism causing the bony problem in this child is:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is s/o acute osteomyelitis while the peripheral smear is indicative of sickle cell anemia. 
 
  • Patients with sickle cell anemia are prone to develop acute osteomyelitis from Salmonella. 




Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 32, 33, 35, 37-39.

questions.text: A young male had a road traffic accident and presented to the Emergency with multiple injuries. After 2 days, he developed tachypnea, petechial rash and became drowsy. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fat embolism.
 
  • It occurs from fat globules originating from the bone marrow following fracture of long bones. 
 
  • Clinically, it manifests as tachycardia, fever, breathlessness, petechiae and confusion. 


GURD'S CRITERIA FOR FAT EMBOLISM SYNDROME:





Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 32, 33, 35, 37-39.

choices.text: Light microscopy shows effacement of foot processes

questions.text: A 10 years old male child presented initially with periorbital edema and anasarca, later on. A clinical diagnosis of minimal change disease was made. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
The true statement among the following options is option 3- Steroid Responsive. 

Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.


Other options:
 
  • Option 1- Minimal change disease is characterized by selective proteinuria with loss of albumin, transferrin and ferritin.  
  • Option 2- Commonly seen in children. 
  • Option 4- Light microscopy of minimal change disease is normal. Effacement of foot processes is a finding on electron microscopy. 


Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 472.

questions.text: On day 4, a neonate was found to have TSH>110 U/L. Ultrasonography revealed an eutopic thyroid gland. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, there is increased level of TSH which is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. 
The most appropriate next line of investigation would be to do a thyroid nuclear scan in order to confirm the presence of thyroid gland. 


Other options:
 
  • Option 2 and 4- Anti-peroxide antibodies are used in diagnosis of transient congenital hypothyroidism as a result of transplacental passage of TSH receptor blocking antibodies. 
 
  • Option 3- Urinary iodine concentration is used as an epidemiological indicator for the level of iodine deficiency in community. 



Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 10th edition, Page no 538.

questions.text: A mother was  worried as her baby has not passed urine even after 20 hours of birth. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is a normal newborn finding. Therefore, the best answer would be to wait and watch along with breastfeeding.
 
  • The first urination should occur by 48 hours.
 
  • The first passage of meconium should occur within 24 hours. 



Reference: Cloherty and Stark's Manual of Neonatal Care, 9th edition, Page no 124.

Campbell-Walsh Urology, 12th edition, Page no 386.

questions.text: A 6 years old child presented with painful swelling of the hand and feet. There is a past history of chest infection 2 years back and he was admitted in the hospital too. Hemoglobin electrophoresis showed HbF and HbS. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with electrophoretic findings of HbF and HbS is suggestive of sickle cell disease. 


Other options:
 
  • Option 1- Beta thalassemia is characterized by microcytic hypochromic cells with aniso and poikilocytosis, target cells. Hb electrophoresis will show increased HbA2 and HbF. 
 
  • Option 2- Anemia of chronic disease is mediated by IL-6 and is characterized with normocytic normochromic anemia along with underlying chronic systemic inflammatory disease- eg Rheumatoid Arthritis. 
 
  • Option 3- HbC disease occurs due to mutation in b-globin chain where glutamate is replaced with lysine in 6th position. PBS shows hexagonal HbC crystals. Hb electrophoresis shows increased HbC levels. 



Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 394, 627.

Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 641-644.

questions.text: A 9 years old child presented to the Pediatrics OPD with the complaints of colicky abdominal pain and melena. On examination, palpable purpura was noted over buttocks and legs. Such a case should be treated by:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein's purpura.
  • Glucocorticoids are used in the treatment of HSP. 

It classically involves the following systems-

1. Skin- Palpable purpura-lower extremities, buttocks.

2. Joints- Arthralgia and arthritis affecting large joints of lower limb.

3. GIT- Abdominal pain, vomiting, intussusception. 



Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 628, 629.

questions.text: A child was subjected to routine hematological investigations and the peripheral blood smear showed microcytosis, hypochromia and target cells. His RBC indices were low MCV (60 fl), low MCH. RBC count was 5.2 x 106/ microL. Which investigation should be done to arrive at a clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear showing microcytic hypochromic cells along with Mentzer index < 13 is suggestive of thalassemia. Therefore, the next step in evaluation would be to estimate HbA2 levels. 

Mentzer Index= MCV/RBC count.
It is used to distinguish iron deficiency anemia from thalassemia.

Mentzer index
  • > 13: Iron deficiency anemia
  • < 13 : Thalassemia trait/ intermedia



Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 340-342..

Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 644, 645, 647, 654, 655, 658.

questions.text: A child born by normal vaginal delivery, had brief attacks of contraction of neck and trunk. There are jerky movements of hands as well. The episode is followed by crying. EEG showed hypsarrhythmia. Best drug to manage such a case:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with EEG findings of hypsarrythmia is suggestive of West Syndrome.
The drug of choice for West syndrome is ACTH. 

Note- Drug of choice for West Syndrome when associated with tuberous sclerosis is Vigabatrin. 


EEG features of seizure disorders-

1. Lennox Gastaut syndrome- 1.5-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts

2. Absence Seizures- 3 Hz spike and dome pattern

3. Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy- 4-5 Hz spike

4. West Syndrome-Hypsarrythmia- high voltage waves with chaotic background ( Tall Himalayan Waves ) 



Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 555, 556.

questions.text: A 3 years old child presented with anorexia, irritability and abdominal bloating. There is a history of passing foul-smelling stools which stick to the pan. The condition was associated with HLA DQ2. What is the best treatment for such a patient?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical scenario of abdominal bloating, anorexia, irritability and passage of foul smelling stools along with positive class II HLA-DQ2 is consistent with diagnosis of celiac disease. 

Food items avoided in celiac disease
Mnemonic - BROW
 
  • B-Barley
  • R-Rye
  • O-Oats
  • W-Wheat

Food items allowed in celiac disease -
Mnemonic - So MRP
 
  • So- Soyabean
  • M- Maize
  • R-Rice
  • P-Potato 



Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 297.

questions.text: An infant is having many episodes of vomiting and passing loose stools. He is lethargic and is not taking breastfeed. Skin when pinched goes back very slowly. Infant is having:
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation of drowsiness, lethargy and inability to feed with delayed skin pinch is suggestive of severe dehydration as per IMNCI guidelines. 
 
  • Rotavirus and enterotoxigenic E. Coli are the most important causes of acute diarrhea in children. 


Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 287-289.
